Somebody came running down and told me that, despite that mandate, the Whitlam government had been turfed out, tossed out, by the activities of the then Governor-General and the then Leader of the Opposition, Malcolm Fraser, whom I have less respect for than the gentleman I mentioned a moment ago. However, I later came to regard Malcolm Fraser as not being too bad a prime minister because there were a few things he did which I thought were much better than what we are currently being blessed with.

At the end of the day, I think the activities of the then Governor-General and those people who gave him advice did serious damage to the political fabric of this country and, some 23 years later, are still worthy of being reflected upon by people in this place and in the broader community. The Whitlam government had a mandate—there was no argument about that. They faced the people in 1974 and they were elected to govern. The term of their commission was some three years. It was cut short—dramatically by about 18 months—by the Senate at that time. It decided, despite all of the conventions—conventions which had been rigorously kept to in Westminster systems around the globe—to starve the Australian government of supply.

Much has been written of this particular period. There are a couple of salient points that I want to bring out in my address here today. The first one is the concept that a government has a commission. That commission, that mandate to govern, which should not be interfered with by the Senate, was, I believe, seriously undermined in 1975. I was enraged in 1975, as were a number of other people, because that very important principle not only was called into question but also, in many respects, was slaughtered on that particular day.

We all know what happened. The election was held some five weeks later; the Labor Party did not win that election. That became the other point of 1975, that the end justifies the means. I remember seeing some of the characters involved in that 1975 assassination of the Whitlam government cheering—and, if I remember rightly, I think the now Prime Minister was one of those who had a glass of champagne in his hand and was cheering when he heard that the Whitlam government had been sacked and dismissed.

I now find myself in a position where the same people are lecturing us here on mandates. It is a bit rich to have people like the Prime Minister suddenly say that he has a mandate and Whitlam never had a mandate. For that matter, when we had a whole pile of other reforms that we wanted to get through here in the 13 years under Labor, we did not have a mandate for them either for whatever reason. The people back in 1974 and 1975 who brought down the Whitlam government did not believe in mandates then but, suddenly, when the role is reversed they believe in them now.

Let us have a look at this concept of a mandate. What does it really involve? One of the most important things about a mandate is if you offer a plan to the public of Australia and give them a chance to vote on that particular proposal—if you are up-front about it and say, `This is what we are proposing. We are not going to do it at midnight and enact it at 9 o'clock the next morning. We want you to vote on it; we want you to deliberate on it; we want you to make your mind up on it. When you go into the polling box, we want to make sure that you are clear about the implications of what you are voting for.' Before my colleagues on this side think I am making out a case for the enemy on this, I hasten to add that I will come back to that point in just a moment.

On 3 October this year the government clearly had a large number of people go and vote under no illusion whatsoever that they would be voting for what was supposedly called tax reform—what we all know is really a cover for the goods and services tax, the GST. There is no doubt that a large number of people went in there and voted for this particular tax. But, sadly, a much larger number went into the polling box and did not vote for the GST at all. They were under no illusion either. As I understand it, 52 per cent of people went in and voted against this government's GST.

Back in 1989 in South Australia, we had a government that was elected with 48 per cent of the vote. We never heard the end of it from the Liberal Party: we had no authority to govern, no right to govern and should not sit in the Treasury benches; and the mugs in my show agreed with them. But what happened then was that the Liberal Party said, `You have no mandate for anything.' The same people who said that then are now saying, `No, we've got a mandate. We only got 48 per cent of the vote. We just managed to trick a few key electorates and we did a pretty good job of that.' When you have $50 million worth of taxpayers' funds and a few smart alecs that know how to run manipulative campaigns in a number of marginal seats, it is not hard at all to exercise those sorts of things. That is no mandate whatsoever, and I will elaborate further on that. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: —I would like to take this opportunity to describe yet another Northern Territory Country-Liberal Party government initiative that has been a resounding success story. On Sunday 22 March the Alice Springs Desert Park celebrated its first year of operation. The 1,300 hectare Alice Springs Desert Park is a world-class tourist attraction that also plays a vital role in research into and conservation of Australia's desert flora and fauna. During its first year, almost 86,000 visitors enjoyed the park's attractions, and this number is sure to grow significantly in a very short time. One of those 86,000 visitors was a man who is synonymous with nature and conservation throughout the world, Sir David Attenborough. His description of the park as `unsurpassable' in the visitors' book and subsequent comment in the local newspaper the Centralian Advocate that `there is no museum or wildlife park in the world that can match it' is high praise indeed and well deserved. Sir David's comments are a ringing endorsement of the efforts that the Northern Territory government and the Parks and Wildlife Commission of the Northern Territory have put into ensuring that the park is a unique and very significant facility.

speech.para: The $20 million park is located just out of Alice Springs and is nestled at the base of the spectacular MacDonell Ranges. This location, amidst such beautiful scenery, adds to the experience of the park and reflects the careful and long-term planning that has gone into all aspects of the park. Ken Johnson, Regional Director South of the Parks and Wildlife Commission, had a vision for the park. He foresaw that `the park will be the premier facility in the nation for displaying and interpreting plants and animals and landscapes of the vast arid zone as well as their traditional use by Aboriginal people'. To see that vision achieved so spectacularly must be very satisfying and gratifying, and I congratulate him and his staff on this achievement.

The 40 staff of the Alice Springs Desert Park look after over 350 plant species and more than 120 animal species in three major Australian desert habitats—the desert rivers, sand country and woodlands. Of the animal species represented, 22 are mammals, 11 of which are threatened or endangered. They include species such as the Greater Bilby, the Mala and the Central Rock-rat, which are several of the more endangered species involved in successful captive breeding programs. These animals represent part of the park's role as a vital research centre, actively involved in the conservation of rare and threatened desert species.

The Alice Springs Desert Park is an excellent tourist facility and plays an important educational, research and conservation role that makes it a model for and sets a very high benchmark for similar facilities worldwide to aspire to. It is particularly remarkable that the park has achieved all that it has in the short time that it has been operating. The park celebrated its first birthday in March this year and only last month won a major national tourism award. But before I move on to this most recent tourism award, let me list some of the other awards that this marvellous attraction has received, such as the Territory and National categories for a Case Earth Award. The master plan of the park received awards before the park was even open, winning an occasional special award from the Royal Australian Institute's National Awards for Planning Excellence in 1995 and 1996. The master plan also received a Judges Special Acknowledgment Award from the Australian Institute of Landscape Architects Queensland group in 1997.

The park has received national recognition from the Australian Institute of Landscape Architects, winning a National Project Award of Merit. At the recent Tourism Council of Australia 1998 Australian Tourism Awards, the Alice Springs Desert Park won the National Award for Tourism Development Projects. This prestigious award is well deserved and was only one of several that Northern Territory tourist operators received. I congratulate them on this excellent result, which is a good indication of the strength and competitive nature of the tourist industry in the territory.

Northern Territory Adventure Tours won in the category of Tour and Transport Operations—Major, and two operations located at what is arguably the most recognisable tourist attraction in Australia, Uluru, or Ayers Rock, also received recognition. In the category of Tourism Restaurants, the Sounds of Silence restaurant had its uniqueness and popularity acknowledged and Ayers Rock Resort Management Pty Ltd won the highly competitive Meetings Industry category.

In the year 2000 Uluru will be the focus of world attention when it is the starting point for the Olympic flames journey around Australia, with territory athlete Nova Peris- Kneebone having the honour of carrying the torch first. Nova will no doubt visit the Sails in the Sunset restaurant, dining under the stars in the desert overlooking the rock. She may also visit the Alice Springs Desert Park, which will also undoubtedly be a focus of world attention in 2000, when the spotlight is on Central Australia and the beginning of the torch relay.

The park has great plans for the future, with three new core habitat displays: Mulga, Range and Gorge, costing $7 million and already well advanced. The Gorge habitat display should be especially interesting and spectacular, replicating the environment and habitat areas such as Stanley Chasm, with its water, rock wallabies and sheer walls. A free picnic area will also be a feature of the park. The new exhibits and picnic area will enhance what is already a world class facility and provide yet another world-class attraction in Alice Springs to add to the many attractions and natural wonders that already draw so many interstate and international visitors to Central Australia.

I would also like to make mention of something else that is unique to Alice Springs. This is not an actual attraction but an event—the Honda Masters Games, which is held in Alice every two years. Over 4,500 people participated in the most recent games, from 17 to 24 October. As in past years, the event was a spectacular success, enjoyed by all involved.

The inaugural masters games were held in Alice Springs in 1986 and were the first multi-sport event for mature aged athletes in Australia. The games have gone from strength to strength since that first event, and their phenomenal growth is evidence of the continuing popularity and support for the event.

The Honda Masters Games are known as `the friendly games' and it is very refreshing to see the event live up to its title. The games are played in the true spirit of sport with all participants competing fiercely and to the highest possible level, but not to the detriment of fair play and sportsmanship. Each year, records are broken in the 30 sports that make up the games but it is the emphasis on participating, having a go and attempting to beat a personal best that I admire most.

The games attract competitors from all over Australia and an increasing contingent from overseas. Ages vary greatly, but it is not uncommon to see sprightly 80-year-old competitors showing their stuff. A recent star of the games was 75-year-old Stan Stankovic, who won 15 gold medals in the 75 to 79 age group and broke the previous track and field record of 13 gold medals.

This most recent Honda Masters Games had the added attraction of a couple of other Australian legends of the sporting arena. Ian Chappell, the former great Australian Test cricket captain, proved he is as fiercely competitive as ever by competing in the baseball with the extremely successful Interport baseball team. Evonne Goolagong-Cawley, the tennis legend, also visited Alice Springs for the games, attended a wide variety of events and was reported as being moved by the famous masters' spirit and willingness to have a go. Another great who has previously attended the games is Dawn Fraser.

The games bring many benefits to the town apart from the opportunity to mix with legends such as Stan Stankovic, Ian Chappell, Evonne Goolagong-Cawley and Dawn Fraser. It is estimated that the Alice Springs economy receives an injection of $8 million from the influx of competitors and others related to the games. This is a huge boost for the town.

But the games also provide many other benefits that may not be measured in dollars and cents. The visitors to the games invariably leave with many happy memories and pass on their experiences to friends and relatives in other states and countries. This word of mouth advertising is the best possible form of endorsement and results in the games' growing popularity and in them becoming a fixture on many masters calendars.

The local residents of Alice Springs love the event and support it strongly. The best example of this support is the fact that almost 1,000 residents act as volunteers and assist with all facets of the games' operations. It is an incredible show of community spirit with approximately one in 25 locals being involved in the games as a volunteer. If the Sydney Olympics manage to generate such enthusiasm and drive, then they will be without doubt the most successful Olympics ever.

The masters games are organised by the Northern Territory Department of Sport and Recreation. I applaud the hard work and dedication that are shown by all those involved, particularly that of the games General Manager, Shane O'Leary. An event of this kind is a huge logistical exercise and organisation for the next masters games must begin the day the event finishes. There is no rest for the workers involved.

The eighth Honda Masters Games will be held in Alice Springs from 21 to 28 October in the year 2000. I urge all Territorians and those eligible in the rest of Australia to attend this event as it will be the experience of a lifetime that everyone will absolutely love. It provides the chance for some high-level masters competition, a chance to sample the Territory hospitality and the ideal opportunity to take in the wonders of Central Australia such as Uluru and the Alice Springs Desert Wildlife Park.

It is important on this day, the 11th day of the 11th month, to make mention of the 80th anniversary since the World War I armistice was signed and the guns fell silent in that terrible war. The bravery, suffering and dedication of all Australian troops who fought is well remembered, and should be remembered for generations to come. The armistice has been marked by ceremonies throughout the Northern Territory.

talk.start.para: —I want to talk about an article which was published in the Launceston Examiner shortly after the recently held federal election entitled `Senators, Liberals: Wake up!' The author was Mr Rod Scott of that newspaper. He gave the impression that he was disappointed with the election result that saw a Liberal cabinet minister and the Liberal parliamentary secretary lose their seats in Tasmania. I think everyone now knows that Labor holds all five House of Representatives seats in the state of Tasmania.

speech.para: In the article, Mr Scott was particularly harsh on the worth of Tasmania's 12 senators, suggesting that they did not contribute much to the state. He described this chamber as a chamber of privilege and he implied that senators were basically a waste of time. He said that they were `highly paid' and `remote from the electorate'. I must say: as I understand it, all Labor senators in Tasmania have shopfront offices and receive a great deal of contact from the public, as is the case with many of the other senators in Tasmania.

I must say that Mr Scott's comments do Tasmanian voters a disservice. Firstly, you should be aware that a significant number of voters in Tasmania did not simply vote above the line—that is, the nominated party distribution of preferences ticket—but chose to vote for individual Senate candidates whom they wanted to represent them; that is, they voted below the line. Over 67,000 voters, or 22 per cent of total votes cast, chose to vote in this way in Tasmania. That is in sharp contrast to most of the other states. In New South Wales, only four per cent of voters voted below the line; in Queensland, four per cent; in Victoria, three per cent; South Australia, seven per cent; Western Australia, six per cent; Northern Territory, 14 per cent; and in the ACT, 22 per cent.

In fact, the national average for below-the-line voting at the 1998 federal election in the Senate was five per cent. So Tasmanian voters made, one would argue, an even more deliberate choice in their selection of the members of this chamber who would take their place from 1 July 1999. In that sense I think Mr Scott does a disservice to Tasmanian voters who did make a very deliberate choice and who, I think, well understand the role of this place in relation to representing the interests of Tasmania.

I would have to say this also: the Senate is not a chamber of privilege, as Mr Scott would have us believe. It is the watchdog of the Australian federal system; it is a house of review. It is a source of considered second opinion on a variety of contentious legislation. The fact of the matter is that normally the Senate considers every piece of legislation clause by clause. This is the forum—in which an extensive and efficient committee system operates—through which members of the Australian public can have direct input into the form of legislation, the detail of specific government programs and matters of public policy. Importantly for Tasmania and for the other smaller states, it is the Senate that scrutinises in great detail every Commonwealth budget. So I really think that it is more than, as Mr Scott describes it, `a chamber of privilege'. He also says this in relation to Tasmania and the Senate:
Tasmania is in deep political trouble and the Government Senators are the ones who are going to have to get us out of it.

Tasmania is represented in this parliament by 17 politicians—five members and 12 senators. Of those, there are five senators who are members of the Liberal Party, and there are no senators or members from the National Party.

So I would suggest that it is not simply the five government senators upon whom Tasmania relies in relation to its future and representation in this place. The future prosperity of the state depends upon the hard work and the effective representation by all senators and all members, not only federal parliamentarians but also members of the state parliament and representatives at a local government level. Representation must start at a local community level. Obviously, in terms of the established parties, it finds its way through the party system and it needs to carry through to the floor of this parliament—the House of Representatives and the Senate—as well as the state parliament.

In the end, the voters must consider the merits of the respective policies presented to them by the parties and vote accordingly as they feel at election time. That happened in Tasmania twice in the last few months— firstly, at the state election on 29 August. In that election the then government, the Liberal government, the government of Mr Rundle, was soundly defeated. If you look at the federal election result in Tasmania, this government was defeated in the state of Tasmania; that is, it lost its only two House of Representatives seats and it performed poorly in the Senate.

Both of the major parties took special Tasmanian policies into the federal election. Labor included, amongst other things, a proposal to write off, with no strings attached, $150 million in Commonwealth debt which was held against the state. The coalition had previously said that that would occur if the Tasmanian people would support a proposal to privatise the Hydro-Electric Commission. That was rejected at the state election.

Another important issue that Labor took to the people was the institution of a single untimed local call zone for the state of Tasmania, which would be one of the more important initiatives for both domestic and business users to have been put to the people of Tasmania for some time. Labor also gave a commitment, if elected, to secure the Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme and the Wheat Freight Subsidy Scheme in legislation. I found it curious that Liberal senators opposed these proposals on what appeared to me to be spurious grounds, stating that somehow that would cause some constitutional problem. The inquiries that I undertook revealed that no such problem really did exist. The government's package was put to the people on the basis of the goods and services tax being introduced and at least another 16 per cent of Telstra being privatised and, subject to an inquiry, the balance of Telstra. So, in essence, the government's position was to introduce a GST and to privatise Telstra.

In terms of the two-party preferred vote at a federal level, in Tasmania the outcome was that Labor received somewhere between 55 and 56 per cent of the two-party preferred vote. In Bass, the voters threw out a cabinet minister and elected Michelle O'Byrne, with a swing of just over 4½ per cent. In Lyons, Dick Adams was returned with a swing of over nine per cent. In Braddon, Sid Sidebottom was elected with a swing of a little over 10 per cent—and that was to replace a member of the Liberal Party who was a parliamentary secretary. Harry Quick was returned with an increased majority, as was Duncan Kerr.

Labor attracted 41.6 per cent of the formal primary vote, compared with the Liberal Party's 33.8 per cent. On a two-party preferred basis, Labor achieved somewhere between 55 and 54 per cent of the vote in Tasmania.

Going back to Mr Scott's article, he would also have all 12 senators from Tasmania band together to vote as a block. He argues that on the basis that this is a states house. It is a states house because it guarantees that we have equal representation with other states and, importantly, without the Senate, the smaller states would clearly be swamped by the larger states. For example, the House of Representatives has 50 members representing New South Wales and five from Tasmania. But with increasing integration of economic power, communications systems and transport networks, the work of the Senate is now far more national than state oriented.

Further, given the election results, Mr Scott's block voting proposal would require Tasmanian government senators to vote against the plans to introduce a goods and services tax and to vote against the further sale of Telstra. They would also be required to pressure Senator Alston to implement the Labor plan to have Tasmania operate as a single untimed local call zone.

Tasmania would be a much better place if government senators supported Labor's platform which was put to the people of Tasmania at the last election, but we all know that they will not do that. If one wants to know why, one only has to look at the treatment Senator Watson received earlier in the week.

Senator Watson is an astute politician with considerable expertise in tax matters. He continues to make an important contribution to debate on matters of tax and superannuation in this place. Last Sunday he expressed a view that there were problems with the government's tax plan. He was quoted in the Launceston Examiner as saying:
On the GST, it may be necessary to have the concessions lifting the compensation for those most affected by it, because a large percentage of low income earners' costs go on the cost of living.
On Telstra he was quoted as saying:
Telstra is regarded as an icon, and the bush is concerned about the ability of Telstra in private hands to deliver its service obligations.
He said there was sufficient support in the Liberal Party to change the policy from full privatisation to the sale of only 49 per cent. He said on the ABC AM program on Monday:
A wide spectrum of people, low income earners, have expressed concerns about their ability to cope and I have taken note of that.

He said the government must be seen to have a heart and a social conscience and make some adjustments. He had heard the view of Tasmanian voters about how badly the GST would affect them. In my view, he was responding to that view.

However, by lunchtime on that day he was forced to contradict his earlier remarks. He released a statement—which I suggest might have been released for him—stating that he had changed his mind. His revised position stated that the compensation offered by the Howard government to offset the impact of the GST was `adequate'—note that, `adequate'; not `fair'.

Senator's Watson's AM position was the correct one. The GST is not fair—in fact, it is not adequate—for low and middle income families in Australia. It is certainly not fair for families living in Tasmania. And in the interests of Tasmanian families, Labor's five representatives in the other place and five senators here plan to oppose it all the way.

Despite Mr Scott's apparent disappointment with the results in the last federal election in Tasmania, I can assure Tasmanian voters that their overwhelming endorsement of the Australian Labor Party has not been misplaced.

talk.start.para: —One year ago today I rose in this place to give my first speech and now one year later I am rising to give my first speech in the new parliament. It is good to hear a Labor senator in particular highlighting the value and importance of the upper house and the crucial role it does play in ensuring that the parliament can act as some balance against the executive and the government. I hope Senator O'Brien can convince a few more of his colleagues at state level as well as federal level of the importance of upper houses in playing that important role.

speech.para: I start by offering my congratulations to everyone involved in the recent election, particularly my own party and its leadership team, Senator Meg Lees and Senator Natasha Stott Despoja, for their efforts. The result was that we succeeded in obtaining the highest ever number of Democrat senators in this place, whom we will all gladly welcome on 1 July next year.

Congratulations are also due to all successful candidates from all parties, as well as the Independent member in the other place, and those who have subsequently gained promotion to the ministry or shadow spokesperson roles. Commiserations go to those who were unsuccessful, especially those who suffered the extra blow of losing their seats.

The main purpose of my speech today is to pay a brief tribute to a member of the Democrats who was tragically killed in July this year. It is the first opportunity I have had since that time to pay a tribute to him in this place because this is the first time we have met since that time.

I speak of the death of one of the more promising members of the Democrats in Queensland, a person called Mark Ault who was only 24 years of age. He was actually in Canberra at the conclusion of the sittings of the last parliament in early July. He was down here with many other young Democrats from around Australia attending a conference and seminar. He was among a number of young people who were creating a disturbance in the gallery by applauding when the Telstra bill was surprisingly voted down at the end of that sittings.

He had participated in the conference down here and was heading back to Brisbane to take up the position of president of the Queensland Young Democrats when he was tragically killed in a car accident on the highway. Twenty-four years of age is a very young age at which to die with so many aims and hopes yet to fulfil. As with the death of any young person, losing Mark means losing the great potential he had to further enrich our lives and make the world a better place.

However, Mark's 24 years of life highlight to all of us that we do not need to be around for a very long time to make a very positive impact, because he certainly managed to do it. This is emphasised by the fact that he was around the Democrats and a part of our party for only a relatively short time, yet he had such a positive impact on all of us who had dealings with him.

As well as his involvement in the Young Australian Democrats and the position that he was about to take up as the president of that body in Queensland, he was also a candidate for us in the June state election and was employed on my staff in a relief capacity a number of times. He has left a legacy to be proud of and one which I and many others who knew him, both from inside and outside the party, will strive to remember. We will try to give extra value and purpose to his life by taking on board the example he has set.

In closing I would like to pay tribute—given the date is the 11th day of the 11th month—to all those people who served this country in combat, particularly overseas, and those who made the ultimate sacrifice by giving their lives or those who suffered injury, trauma and hardship as a result. I recognise the value of the role they played and hope that all of us here continue to do what we can to ensure a fairer deal particularly for the veterans in our community.

talk.start.para: —I wish to comment today on an article which was drawn to my attention last week. The article appeared in the Bulletin and is the opinion column written by Andrew Robb. For those who are not aware, Andrew Robb regularly writes for the Bulletin . It is an opinion column. He is obviously entitled to express a view and Mr Robb was the former director of the Liberal Party.

speech.para: The basic theme of the article, which appeared in the Bulletin on 6 October 1998, was a commentary on what he regarded as the significant amount of the money that the Labor Party was spending at that time on the election campaign and the allegation he makes about where that money was coming from.
Mr Robb claims that the amount of money being spent by the Labor Party could well hit $11 million above-the-line expenditure. He states:
Add in $3 million for research and administration costs and the Labor Party is running an unprecedented $25 million campaign, outspending the Liberal Party two-to-one.
I am sure that is not correct. I do not know the actual figures, but I am sure it is not correct. He asks the question, `Where is the money coming from?' He goes on to say:

It will be interesting to see the level of union contribution this time around. Union superannuation funds, which cornered a big part of the fledging super market under the previous Labor government, are still smarting from Coalition legislation which guaranteed a fund-of-choice option, under which employees are offered a choice of three or four funds. This competition has severely curtailed the union super funds' business prospects.

If this Coalition legislation was rolled back by a Beazley Labor government, the union funds would stand to have monopoly control over hundreds of millions more dollars of members' funds, with the union receiving, by law, a very healthy management fee.
Mr Robb was alleging that the Labor Party's campaign to a significant extent was underwritten by what he refers to as `union' superannuation funds.

Unfortunately, like a great number of members of the Liberal Party, Mr Robb has very little knowledge of superannuation and particularly the way in which superannuation law operates in this country. Mr Robb is either ill-informed, totally ignorant or deliber ately misleading in this article. He cannot get the facts straight. He refers to `union' superannuation funds; there is no such thing as a union superannuation fund, despite the persistent tag put on what are called industry superannuation funds by Mr Robb and some others from the Liberal Party.

Industry superannuation funds are set up under trustee law in this country and they are required by law to have what is known as joint trustees—an equal number of trustees from employee representatives and an equal number of trustees from employer representatives. Sometimes the employee trustees are union officials; sometimes the employer representatives are nominees of employer organisations. Quite often they are elected by the employee and employer members of the funds. We do not have union superannuation funds; we have industry superannuation funds where there are an equal number of trustees from employers and employees.

The other important aspect of superannuation that is relevant is that there has to be a majority vote. If the trustees of a superannuation fund decide to spend money, because of the equal number of trustees from employees and employers, there has to be a majority to authorise any expenditure. Mr Robb is either totally ignorant or deliberately misleading in his claim about these superannuation funds. If, in fact, any money is given from an industry superannuation fund to the Labor Party, it would require at least one employer trustee to vote with the employee trustees to authorise such expenditure.
Of course, Mr Robb's ignorance is further exemplified by his comment that I referred to earlier where he said:
Union superannuation funds . . . are still smarting from Coalition legislation which guaranteed a fund-of-choice option . . .

I will not go into the arguments for and against so-called fund-of-choice, which is effectively deregulation with a number of horrific consequences. But the fact is that the legislation he is referring to has not passed into law yet. Mr Robb is claiming that these so-called `union' funds were upset at this legislation and it has not passed into law. He goes on to say:
If this Coalition legislation was rolled back by a Beazley Labor government . . .
It is not even law yet, so he obviously did not know what he was talking about.

Mr Robb goes on to say that the union funds would stand to have monopoly control over hundreds of millions more dollars of members' funds, with the union receiving, by law, a very healthy management fee. That is just totally untrue. We cannot use the word `lie' in this chamber. Under superannuation law in this country, the joint trustees—the employer and union—are required by law to tender out the contracts for the management and investment of the funds. To my knowledge there are very few complaints, if any, about this process—its probity, its correctness. You do not have monies passing from members' superannuation accounts back to the union, yet here he is alleging that that is the system that exists in this country.

So the three central issues that I have dealt with in my contribution today were untrue claims by Mr Robb. As I said when I began, he is entitled to editorialise—it is an opinion column—but he should at least get his facts correct. He is like a significant number of members and senators of this government who simply do not know a great deal about superannuation. What little they do know is based on some sort of ideological objection to superannuation and Australians having decent retirement incomes.

This article is grossly misleading. I will be interested to have a look at the election expenditure returns for respective political parties. I would be surprised if any money came from industry superannuation funds to the Labor Party. There may be some, but I would be surprised if there was any. Certainly I would be very confident that it would not add up to anywhere near $25 million or even one per cent of that.

The irony of this article is that Mr Robb alleges—with no facts to support his claim—that monies were going from superannuation funds to the Labor Party to finance the election campaign. In fact, the Liberal Party had just received $15.7 million, I think—and it is going to go higher—of taxpayers' money to fund the advertising campaign associated with its tax reform program. We had a debate about that in the Senate yesterday. That was the most blatant misuse of an advertising campaign that Australia has ever seen, with funds coming from the taxpayer. That would have been a more appropriate issue for Mr Robb to deal with in his column. Of course, I suppose he has got such a tinge of bias: he was the national director of the Liberal Party.

Mr Robb may have an excuse about his claims in respect of superannuation. I can only assume that Mr Robb was somewhat confused, taken aback, bemused and worried. He probably had just received his superannuation tax assessment or superannuation surcharge. I think that is probably Mr Robb's only excuse for such an appalling lack of knowledge of superannuation. Certainly those who have received the superannuation tax assessment notices have been struck by this new 15 per cent superannuation tax.

The new 15 per cent superannuation tax—much has been said about it in the last few years and much more will be said about it over the next few years—that Mr Costello introduced was in direct contravention of the guarantee not to increase existing taxes that Mr Costello or Mr Howard gave to the Australian people in 1996. What did they do? They introduced an increase in the superannuation tax. As I have said, much has been said about this superannuation tax and much more will be said about it over the coming months and years. I think that can be Mr Robb's only excuse for why he has such a befuddled, ignorant attitude towards superannuation and the way it operates in this country. He must have been shocked and horrified by that superannuation tax assessment notice he would have received. It has somewhat thrown him off the track.

In conclusion, Mr Robb's three central arguments do not have basis in fact. They are grossly incorrect, untrue and misleading. I noticed that in his last paragraph he said he spent a few days on business in London. I understand that Mr Robb does some consultancy work. I have to urge the financial sector of this country to never consider Mr Robb as a consultant to your industry. Given his abysmal lack of knowledge of the operation of superannuation in this country, you could never have any confidence that Mr Robb, as a consultant, would have any idea what he is talking about in representing financial institutions in regard to superannuation issues in this country.

It was very disappointing to see this article from Mr Robb. He really does owe an apology to the industry superannuation funds which were very unfairly besmirched in this way. It will be interesting to see the financial returns for contributions to political parties and how much, if any, was contributed by industry superannuation funds to the Labor Party's election campaign.

Industry superannuation funds in this country are cost effective and have given a very good return to their members. To my knowledge there is little, if any, difficulty with those funds, and I think they serve the interests of Australian's future retirement incomes very well indeed.

talk.start.para: —Today is 11 November—Armistice Day—and some 2½ hours ago in here we recognised that fact, as indeed we should. I think it is appropriate to make a few remarks with respect to this very important occasion.

speech.para: I note with a great deal of interest that Premier Carr and other leaders in Australia have all welcomed the fact that today we are starting to recognise the past and the part played by our armed forces, particularly in the 1914-18 war. I find that somewhat of a contradiction, however, because state education authorities around Australia have just about wiped out the teaching of history as a discipline. Indeed, most of the state high schools and a large number of private high schools now teach hybrid subjects. I can clearly explain the reasons for that. They were put to me by my deputy in a high school some 25 years ago. He told me it was easier to get hold of X number of teachers and X number of classes and tell them to teach whatever they want. So the idea that history as a discipline in particular would be taught with some cognitive levels at every stage from primary school through to senior high school was a casualty of that particular concept of bureaucratic organisation.

I never took that threat all that seriously because I never thought anyone would seriously do that. But, sadly, I stand here today and say that that in fact is now the norm. That unfortunately is what has happened in almost every state. As a consequence, although events such as the one today that we are recognising—the importance of Armistice Day—are now much more in the community's eye and much more in the eye of the leaders in our community, sadly the most important building block of that is now missing—in our schools.

I want to speak about this matter because it seems to me that a country such as Australia, that has only a handful of very significant dates in its past, needs to come to grips with these issues in its education system. These events are at least as important as many of the other things that we put in our curriculum. They are important for the future citizens of this country. They are events that need to be recorded. They are events that need to be retold to the students in our schools. They are events that, unless we take up the challenge, will disappear into obscurity.

This will be particularly so when the last of the diggers from the 1914-18 war are gone. From media reports today, I note that there are something of the order of 66 veterans left. During the course of the estimates hearings last year I asked the Department of Veterans' Affairs what the number in Australia was at that point. That was in November—around this time—last year. The answer was 133. So 1997-98 has been a particularly unkind year to the veterans of the 1914-18 war. I also note the passing earlier this year of the last of the veterans who landed at Gallipoli on 25 April. Sadly, what will happen over the next few years is that our direct connection with these events will disappear.

The purpose of my address here today is not to say that there ought to be more history taught in schools, that it ought to be consequential history or that we need to look at our school curriculums—I think that is very important and significant—but to honour Armistice Day itself. On 11 November, the armistice came very much as a surprise not only in Australia but also in all the belligerent countries. The events of the preceding five or six weeks indicated that the war would end soon. Indeed, the war in many theatres—the war in Mesopotamia, the war in the Middle East, the war against Austria—ended before 11 November.

The significance of 11 November cannot, in my view, be overstated. Not all of the guns fell silent on the Western Front at 11 a.m. on 11 November. In the American sector the fighting continued for well over two hours. In fact, the last man killed was Phillip Adams, a corporal in the American Army. He was killed some two hours and 11 minutes after the armistice. There was news of other casualties coming in as the church bells in England and in other countries were ringing to announce the armistice. What came to an end on 11 November was something that for a generation, and indeed probably for several generations, would be remembered as the Great War.

It would also be remembered as the foulest war that Australian soldiers had ever gone into. In fact, of the 330,000 Australian soldiers who went to this war—out of a population of only 4½ million at that time—some 58,000 would never come back. Of those who did come back, about 120,000 suffered injuries, to varying degrees. All of the soldiers who went overseas during that particular period carried other scars that we today recognise.

We are, as a community, much more sympathetic now to things such as battle fatigue. We are much more sympathetic to the horrors that these people—men and women—went through. One group that is quite often forgotten in this whole exercise is the many women who served, particularly in the 1914-18 war. They served in different capacities—usually in medical capacities, but they served nonetheless. These people saw sights that none of us in our lifetime will ever see. These people worked under the most horrific of conditions—throughout the whole of the 1914-18 conflict in particular—and they carried the scars literally all the way to their graves.

Now, as a community, we look back on some of the events that have taken place. In the media during this week we have had comments about VC recipients who were charged. One person was charged with desertion after a particularly horrible period of battle when he apparently snapped. He was sentenced to a period of imprisonment. I think it is appropriate for us to say, as a community, that we need to remember today the suffering of these men and women who fought in the 1914-18 war and, indeed, in other wars.

We need to make a clear statement that we, as a country, owe them a great deal. We recognise what they went through. We also recognise what their families went through when these people came home. I think that quite often is forgotten. These men and, in many instances, women, came home to what was a normal life in societies in Australia, Britain, the United States and the other countries that were involved in these conflicts. When they came home their family life was resumed. Some of them resumed duties as fathers and some as mothers; some of them went on to have more children. They carried with them the scars of events they could never talk about. I think it is good that our community—and in particular my generation, which has not had to suffer this level of terrible conflict—is now recognising this.

It is beyond the scope of my address here today to go to the various events in the 1914-18 war that Australian soldiers participated in. But I think it is sufficient to say that, apart from Gallipoli, which is the focal point of our 25 April celebrations every year, the Australian Army participated in all of the major onslaughts on the Western Front, and it played a pivotal role in the Middle East in the Palestine campaign.

Certainly, the five Australian divisions that were present in Western Europe were used as the shock troops, and starting in the middle of July 1916 that was the role that they would play all the way up to Armistice Day. The battle of Passchendaele, the battles on the Somme and the great offensives of the Ger man Army in 1918 all saw the Australian soldiers, with their determined will, hold the enemy or advance against tremendous odds. It saw the Australian soldiers whittled down in numbers and those five divisions run down considerably.

By the end of the war, the Australian Army had suffered, per head of population, enormous casualties—casualties much greater than any of the other combatants in the Commonwealth forces. They did not suffer more casualties than the British, but they did suffer more per head of population. One of the reasons for the level of casualties is that the soldiers themselves fought so well that they were used time and time again as shock troops.

I think, after 80 years now, it is important for us to look back with a fresh vision on these days. I think it is important to raise some of the questions that have been raised this week. I commend the various media outlets that have given so much of their time today in the various newspapers around this country to recognise the enormous contributions that these men and women made, and to point out to the community the importance of 11 November.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 1.42 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —by leave—I inform the Senate that Senator Robert Hill, Minister for Environment and Heritage, will be absent from the Senate chamber for question time today and tomorrow, 11 and 12 November. Senator Hill is in Buenos Aires attending the fourth meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Framework on Climate Change. In his absence, I will take questions relating to the portfolios of the Prime Minister, Foreign Affairs and Trade, and Forestry and Conservation; Senator Minchin will take questions relating to the portfolio of Environment and Heritage.

—My question is directed to Senator Alston, Acting Leader of the Government. Can the minister confirm reports that the head of the Prime Minister's department, Mr Max Moore-Wilton, recently berated portfolio secretaries for their failure to market the government's achievements and policies? Can the minister confirm that Mr Moore-Wilton told a meeting of portfolio secretaries that the Prime Minister was only happy with three of their number? Do Mr Moore-Wilton's comments accurately reflect the Prime Minister's view, or are they an exaggeration or, worse, an outright distortion? Will the Prime Minister rule out a repeat of the purging of departmental secretaries that occurred following the 1996 federal election?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —It is clear that nothing has changed. After one of the biggest drubbings in electoral history—which I would have thought would have told you that you needed to concentrate on policies—all you are doing is relying on a bit of scuttlebutt you have read in the newspaper. Mr Max Moore-Wilton has not spoken to me. No-one else has conveyed to me any private thoughts that might have—
—Nobody talks to you!

—They are not supposed to tell me what goes on about any briefings that might or might not occur between the head of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and other departmental secretaries. But whether or not they choose to tell me, they did not on this occasion and I have no reason to think anything of the sort was discussed. In fact, the selling of policies was the responsibility of ministers and backbenchers; they did a magnificent job in that regard.
—Like the tax package.

—The score is on the board. As Mr McMullan said on election night, there are no second prizes. In a two-horse race, if you come second you come last—and you know that. This is a unique opportunity for you to lift your game, but you refuse to do so.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. As the minister has indicated that the selling of the government's so-called achievements is the responsibility of ministers and backbenchers, can I ask whether Mr Moore-Wilton was speaking on behalf of the government in stipulating failure to adequately market the government's achievements as the criterion for assessing the government's senior managers? Isn't this measure grossly unfair for those senior executives who were responsible for trying to salvage the government's botched health insurance and nursing home policies and those who had to take the rap for the Job Network disaster? Shouldn't ministers be taking the blame for their own incompetence?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The logic of that is breathtaking. I have just told Senator Faulkner and the Senate that, indeed, I am not in a position to confirm anything that Mr Max Moore-Wilton might have said or not said—and Senator Faulkner then asks me whether what he said was authorised. It really beggars belief.
—I asked you whether ministers should be taking the blame for their own incompetence.

—If we are talking about policy, might I say that I was well served by my department; I think others were as well. What this really ought to be about is focusing on who had policies and who did not. I think Laurie Oakes got it pretty right today when he said that Labor's choice to play it safe means that Kim Beazley should get a kick in the behind and someone ought to tell him that his tactics did not work.

answer.para: The fact is that, during that campaign period when policies had to be sold, we were out there selling them—but your leader was busy gorging on humble pie when he did not have a recipe for the future. His fundamental problem is too much tucker, not enough ticker. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I ask a question of the Acting Leader of the Government, Senator Alston. Senator Alston, as a result of the coalition's sound economic policies, Australia has successfully withstood the severe economic downturn in the Asian region. How does the government intend to fulfil the clear mandate it has been given by the Australian people to continue its record of sensible economic management? Are you aware also of any alternative approaches to economic management that may or may not be worthy of consideration by the government?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Boswell for a very important question, because this goes to the heart of the difference between the parties. One party, the coalition, was out there selling policies that were in Australia's best interests; the Labor Party was out there selling a scare campaign, which failed monumentally. As Senator Boswell very rightly points out, not only did the approach that we took to economic management stand us in very good stead; it has shielded us from the Asian crisis. Every country in the region, outside of Australia and China, is in recession. As a result of our commitment to sensible economic management, we continue to enjoy strong economic growth, low inflation, record low interest rates and strong employment growth. Indeed, preliminary figures released today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that the economy grew by a revised 4.4 per cent in 1997-98, up from the four per cent rate previously reported. So, in the face of global economic uncertainty, this is truly a remarkable result.

answer.para: This results from the fact that we had the economic fundamentals right, as was attested to by Treasury in its latest Economic roundup, where it said:

The current approach to macro-economic policy and the impact of micro-economic reform have strengthened the stabilisation mechanisms in the Australian economy, making it more resilient to disturbances.
The Reserve Bank says pretty much the same thing:
The Australian economy has weathered the first year and a half of a very difficult international environment exceptionally well.

The lesson ought to be clear to all those doomsayers who are out there trying to sell down the Australian economy. Poor old Gareth Evans said that all the evidence is that the Australian economy is on a precipice, hanging on by its fingertips. Of course he fell over the cliff, and so did Labor's economic strategy.

Senator Boswell points out that we did have a clear mandate given to us by the Australian people. We will continue our record of sensible economic management. I know of no other alternatives that are worthy of consideration by the government. I say yet again, as Laurie Oakes says, that Labor's failure of leadership was Beazley's failure. The Labor leader simply grabbed tax credits as a gimmick to stack up against the coalition's tax reform package. We had the guts to tackle tax reform. We had the guts to make the changes. Your blokes simply had too much tucker and not enough ticker.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the Prime Minister's announcement in September that the ministerial code of conduct, which he introduced with such righteous fanfare following the 1996 election, has now been scrapped. Has a new code of conduct been prepared now that the election is over, as promised by the Prime Minister? What changes have been made? When is the code to be made public? Given that the Prime Minister promised to lift parliamentary standards, is it the intention of the government to actually enforce any proposed new code of conduct?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —It is totally incorrect to say that the code of conduct has been scrapped. There is a code of conduct that ministers are expected to abide by. If there are any changes, we will let you know. In the meantime, if you are serious about raising the standards and if you truly do aspire to one day be office holders, perhaps you might look at releasing a similar code of conduct for shadow ministers. I am sure that hell will freeze over before you do.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Prime Minister for letting us know of any changes. Does the minister believe that the parliament and the public are entitled to know of any changes, if there are any, to the ministerial code of conduct? Is it not true that the Prime Minister has had to rewrite his code of conduct not on the basis of principle but on the basis of compliance with the venal and self-interested approach of his own ministers?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I am not aware of any rewriting. To the extent that there are changes made and they are required to be made public, of course we will make them public. We will take the parliament into our full confidence at the appropriate time. As I said, if and when there are any changes we will let you know.

—My question, which is directed to the Assistant Treasurer, relates to tax reform. Will the minister explain how the implementation of tax reform on 1 January 2000 will provide substantial benefits for the Australian people and the Australian economy?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Synon for that important question. The government went to the election with a proposal for a bold tax reform program that is in the interests of the Australian economy and the Australian community. It is really the biggest tax plan that has been put forward in this country certainly since the 1950s. It changes the whole structure of personal taxation, indirect taxation, business taxation and tax administration in this country.

answer.para: The polls showed that the Australian people agreed that tax reform was necessary, that it was good for the nation and that it was good for them individually. The Australian people embraced tax reform and gave the government a mandate to deliver a new tax system for the new century. This was achieved despite Labor's very dishonest campaign against the tax reform plan.

Our plan will create much stronger incentives to work by cutting marginal tax rates and by reducing taper rates at which social security and family benefits are withdrawn. The GST will allow the abolition of the wholesale sales tax system, which we do not support but which the Labor Party apparently does, and a range of other state taxes and charges. It will allow fuel costs for business to be significantly reduced. It will recognise the costs of raising a family and provide substantial encouragement for people to take out private health cover. It will provide a sure footing for state governments, which deliver critical infrastructure to our community.

The Australian community voted in favour of tax reform to be delivered by 1 July 2000. To give effect to these wishes of the Australian people, it is necessary for legislation to be passed by this parliament by 1 July next year. I believe that the Labor Party is acting in contempt of the Australian people. Mr Beazley said this:
We will manoeuvre tactically in whatever way we can to try to procure the defeat of this legislation. We will also—

talk.start.para: —Hear, hear!

—`Hear, hear,' they say. After all, we went to an election. The central issue of the election, which the Labor party would agree, was tax reform. We happened to win the election, and it happened to lose the election. We therefore believe that we have a very clear mandate from the Australian people. Mr Beazley and the Labor Party refuse to recognise that mandate. What we are seeing is an attempt by the Labor Party to defeat in this chamber tax reform which it could not defeat in the election. As I said, tax reform was the central issue. Tax reform was debated extensively. The Australian people now want tax reform. It is our view that the Senate should now get behind the government and ensure that this tax reform bill is passed.

—My question without notice is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Alston. Can the minister confirm that former Minister Somlyay consulted with the opposition during the federal election campaign on service delivery arrangements for the Cocos Islands in accordance with the caretaker convention? Can the minister also confirm that Minister Downer consulted with the opposition on the proposed visit of a senior Chinese official and that Minister Minchin consulted with the opposition on an amendment to a determination under the MOPS Act? Why then did the government not consult with the opposition on the substance of the government's $100 million gas crisis relief package for Victoria, announced the day before the 1998 federal election?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I do not remember the Labor Party having any objection to that policy proposal; indeed I took it that you were very supportive of it. I am not aware of whether or not there were any consultations that might have occurred. I am aware of those matters that are brought to my attention. This was not brought to my attention. I have no idea whether there was felt to be a requirement to do it, but the bottom line is that this was an announcement that was critically needed, that was very much appreciated and about which you said absolutely nothing.

answer.para: You no doubt squirmed because it is the very sort of thing that you probably thought you should have announced. I remember Mr Beazley making some announcement—I don't know, what was he going to do? Declare a national day of emergency or something? I do not think he consulted us about that. I do not think for a moment that he would have been inhibited in anything that he might have done to address that crisis. We made decisions that were not only in the national interest but were very much designed to address the emergency requirements of that state, and we did it in a way that I think addressed all of those needs.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you seem remarkably uninformed about these matters, but I ask you: has the minister's attention been drawn to the comments made by the Treasurer, Mr Costello, in relation to the gas measures when he said:

question.para: . . . in caretaker mode you can actually do things by agreement with the Opposition and I can't imagine there would be any disagreement in relation to this.

Given that the Treasurer clearly understood the caretaker conventions—and clearly the Treasurer also indicated that they did apply in regard to the gas measures—why was this particular proposal not discussed with the opposition before its announcement?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I will make some inquiries and see if there is anything more that can be added to the answer I have already given. The fact is that this was emergency relief which had to be announced as soon as possible. I have no idea whether Mr Costello was being quoted in relation to the gas crisis.
—You had time to go to your advertising agency.

—It is your question. You did not bother to link it to that. You simply said that Mr Costello made some remarks about the caretaker mode. He may well have made some remarks about the caretaker mode, but I do not know what they related to and I will make some inquiries.

—My question is to Senator Kemp, the Minister representing the Treasurer. My question is about the false impression, fostered by your government, that every Australian fully understood your tax package when they voted on 3 October.

question.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senators on my right will cease interjecting. Senator Kemp needs to hear the question that he is being required to answer.
—In fact the Treasurer said of the election a few days afterwards:

question.para: You had a system where a government came clean with the Australian people and put out a new tax system, in detail.

How does this false impression sit with the hundreds and hundreds of letters that we—and I am sure most senators—are now receiving from individuals, industry associations and not-for-profit organisations expressing concern with the details in the tax package? How does this shonky argument sit with comments from Mr David Vos, who said:
Most of the consternation that exists within most of the sectors is because not all of the policy has been revealed by the government.
Minister, what is your response?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —In relation to the comment by Mr Vos, I do not think you actually quoted the first comment he made. Perhaps in the supplementary, when you stand up—I assume you are reading from the AAP—you might actually quote the first number of sentences that Mr Vos said. I think that will place an entirely different spin.

—It is quite important, if you pick out a paragraph which is highly selective. Mr Vos also said that large numbers of people will be happier after the report because there are some issues which he is looking at.

answer.para: It is not surprising that people are writing to the government. I am surprised that they think they can achieve much by writing to you, Senator, but it is not surprising that they are writing and bringing particular issues to the government's attention. Of course the government looks carefully at those matters which are raised and they will be taken into account in the drafting of the legislation.

On the substance of your question, Senator Lees, we put out a major policy of 200 pages. Can I point out to you that no government has ever been elected on such an extensive and detailed tax policy, and this has been extensively debated during the election. In fact I would have to say that it was the central issue in the election. Everywhere everyone went the issue was tax reform. The Labor Party wanted to make the election on tax reform, and we were happy to make the election on tax reform. That was the issue, and we won.

In such an extensive tax reform program, of course people will be asking particular questions. Of course they want particular issues clarified and there are some issues which they are putting to government, and the government is reading their representations carefully.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, could I suggest that you may like to look through some of the mail, because people are writing to us enclosing letters they have written to the government that remain unanswered weeks and weeks after they have written them. I ask, Minister: how do you respond to the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission, who say:

question.para: The Commission was given assurances by Senator Newman following the release of the Coalition's tax reform package that there would be wide consultation with the churches and the community sector before the implementation of the GST legislation. Clearly, the mandate the Treasurer has given to the Tax Consultative Committee means that now there will be limited, if any, public examination of the impact of the proposed tax reform on low income people and families.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Senator Lees again raised the issue of people writing. People write all the time about the current tax system. We constantly receive letters on the current tax system and most of those are letters which complain. That is the first point. Secondly, this tax package has been out for a long time. All groups are fully aware of the issues which are raised in the tax package. A lot of those groups have made their views known to government and, where they have, those views have been passed on to the Vos committee for consideration.

answer.para: I am not precisely sure whether you quoted my colleague correctly, but there has been extensive consultation. The issues those groups have raised have been taken into account. I think that was one of the points Mr Vos made on the radio this morning.

talk.start.para: —I remind senators both asking questions and answering them of the provisions of standing order 186.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Given that Mr Howard has indicated he will not be declining a one-on-one meeting with Dr Mahathir at the APEC forum, will the Prime Minister place the treatment of Anwar Ibrahim at the top of his agenda for this meeting? If he won't, why not?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —There are a number of aspects of any bilateral relationship that obviously need to be canvassed. I know it might suit your purposes to suggest that this is the pre-eminent issue, but APEC is essentially an Asia-Pacific economic commission.
—We invented it; don't tell us about it.

—Indeed, and you should know that the `E' stands for economic. All I am pointing out is that it is principally concerned with economic issues. It does provide an opportunity for discussions on a range of other issues. The Prime Minister has already made it clear that he is not impressed with the way in which the issue has been handled internally. The extent to which the Prime Minister wishes to pursue that matter at APEC will be a matter for judgment.

answer.para: We understand that other countries, particularly the United States, have made public statements about what they will or will not canvass in the bilateral discussions, but as far as Australia is concerned we will look at what is in Australia's best interests. We are very conscious of the need to advocate the full and proper protection of human rights in the region and we clearly have concerns about the treatment of Anwar Ibrahim to date.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. This is in a bilateral meeting, not in the formal economic component of the meeting, Minister. Since you have described the process, would you mind telling us what is in the best interests of Australia? Why won't the government place this issue at the top of the agenda? All I want is an answer to that question: why won't it place it at the top of the agenda?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The fact that bilateral discussions occur does not mean that they have to be on subjects other than those discussed in the plenary sessions. Clearly, the economic relationship between Australia and Malaysia is the pre-eminent issue for consideration. The Prime Minister has already expressed his concerns about the direction of the political situation in Malaysia. We have also expressed our hope and expectation that Anwar will be accorded all rights to which he is entitled under Malaysian law.
—Hopeful, are you?

—I know you would like to personally go there and do what you can to solve the problem. We recall that Senator Cook was never able to make more than about two meetings in a day. I can imagine what Senator Cook did in relation to bilateral discussions. This is the bloke who said that his final program had to be prepared for him two weeks before departure, no more than four calls should be arranged for any one day and time should always be allowed for a briefing and a cup of tea. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the thousands of deaths and injuries caused by Hurricane Mitch in the poorest countries of Central America. What humanitarian aid has been given or promised by the Australian government and by the rest of the world? In view of the economic devastation and continuing crippling debt in these particular countries, is Australia supporting the proposals for a debt write-off?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —We certainly are very conscious of the devastation to which Senator Harradine refers and it is obviously a tragedy of immense proportions. The Australian government already announced on 7 November an assistance package by way of emergency relief of $1 million. Funds will be provided through aid organisations already active in the region. There will be $500,000 to Australian NGOs to supplement their own resources in providing immediate relief to victims, $250,000 to the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs to support their efforts to improve urgently needed road and air transport capacity and $250,000 to the International Federation of the Red Cross to assist with basic health care.

answer.para: We will be announcing this week the further details of NGO programs that will be supported. This is a generous contribution from the Australian government. It is made on the basis of our capacity and our concern in the region. We are at the same time providing significant humanitarian aid to places such as Papua New Guinea, China and Bangladesh following floods in those countries. We are obviously playing a key role in addressing the financial and economic concerns in Indonesia.

I am not aware of the extent to which the Australian government might be involved in any discussions about debt write-offs, but I will ascertain an answer to that question and at the same time I will find out what contributions are being made by other countries to what is clearly a disaster of devastating proportions.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Alston. Can the minister confirm the Prime Minister's commitment on page 32 of the tax reform package that `the government will consult widely after the election on the GST'? Did he also promise that `interested parties will be fully involved in the consultation and implementation phase because consultation is needed to ensure the design and draft legislation deliver the government's policy objectives'? Did the Prime Minister also reassure voters prior to the election that the government has `two years to do it or 18 months to do it'? Why then has he truncated the consultation process to 17 days, a time frame that even the chair of his own committee, Mr David Vos, has described as inadequate?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The monumental hypocrisy of the Labor Party knows no bounds. They have not the slightest interest in further consultation because their minds are absolutely made up. Despite the fact that, if anything, the election should have taught you that you needed sensible alternative policies, you went for the quick fix. You went for the policy free approach.

answer.para: If there was one issue above all else that was canvassed exhaustively during the campaign, it was tax reform, and the GST in particular. You did not miss an opportunity on a daily basis to get out there and perform stunts. You had the Leader of the Opposition humiliating himself on a daily basis to try to desperately draw attention to the GST and all its negative implications. It is not as if we are starting from scratch. It is not as if we have suddenly pulled something out of our back pocket after the election, as you did when you ripped up l-a-w, law; as you did when we found out about the Kirribilli deal; as you did on a whole range of issues. This was something that was transparently crawled over by every interest group in the country on a very detailed basis. So you have to look at consultation in a relative framework.

The consultation process that has been announced will provide every opportunity—and, undoubtedly, if there is a committee established of this Senate to further examine the process—for every interest group to put forward all sorts of submissions. The legislation does not take effect, as we know, for a long time yet, and there will clearly be every opportunity for people to make their positions felt. But the consultation process that the Prime Minister announced before the election is one that we do think is important. That is why we have announced the arrangements that we have.

There will be a special Premiers Conference on 13 November. The taxation consultative committee has been established to undertake a targeted consultation process. The Ralph review of business taxation has been established to consult on the business tax reforms. The taxation task force will be supported by a group of working committees, and there will be a small business consultative committee. There are a whole range of avenues by which people can make suggestions. We assume that the great bulk of those will be acting in good faith and will be wanting to sensibly explore the implications. This is completely unlike the Labor Party, which has not the slightest bit of interest in doing anything other than ensuring that our tax reform package, which was supported at the last election, never sees the light of day.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, are we to take from this farcical backdown on consultation by the Prime Minister that the commitment to tax food, children's clothing, textbooks and over-the-counter medicine was a core promise but the commitment to consult widely was non-core and made only for grubby political advantage?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I do not think I have anything to add, Madam President.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, Senator Minchin. Minister, how will the government's plan to build an internationally competitive tax system in Australia assist business to create more jobs? Secondly, is the minister aware of any alter native proposals for reform of Australia's business tax system?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources
