talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Ferguson for his question, which I want to begin answering with a quote. Someone said:

answer.para: The easy road in politics lies in the preservation of sacred cows. In Labor's case this now means turning a blind eye to the failings of the old economy and the old welfare state.

I think any member of the coalition would be proud to have expressed a sentiment about Labor with such eloquence. But this was not a coalition member; it was actually the Labor member for Werriwa, Mark Latham. He has become I think the modern equivalent of that very brave young man who yelled out, `The Emperor's got no clothes.' As the Beazley Labor Party passes by, there's Mark Latham yelling out, `You've got no policy clothes.' Thank God for Mark Latham!

We have a situation where the current tax system has become one of Labor's great sacred cows. It was not always the case, of course. When Emperor Keating was in charge of the Treasury, he did agree and understand that the tax system was a sacred cow that had to be blown away. I seem to recall that the current leader, Mr Beazley, agreed with him. But now they are in opposition, and now they retreat to defending the old economy and the old welfare state. When Labor went to the election, their idea of tax reform that they put to the Australian people was, `Let's have a retrospective tax on capital gains.' Terrific! `Let's put a new tax on four-wheel drives.' What a brilliant policy! Who was the political genius who dreamed that up? I understand the New South Wales Right has a hunting party out to find them. I wish you luck, because we were staggered when you came out with that policy.

We have a Labor Party that is defending—and a coalition party that is going to overturn—a tax system that resulted in the recent completion of a court case in the Federal Court that took 2½ years to work out whether frozen yoghurt for the purposes of the tax system should be classified as yoghurt, which is tax free, or ice-cream, which has a tax on it. They took 2½ years to work out what to do with frozen yoghurt. In the end I think they said, `Well, if the frozen yoghurt tastes like ice-cream, it should be taxed as ice-cream. But, if it doesn't, then it is tax free and it will be counted as yoghurt.' That is what the Labor Party is defending. That is what we want to get rid of.

The people on 3 October rejected your position on tax. They threw it out—80 to 67—and they voted for our tax reform plan. Our tax reform plan is all about reducing the tax burden on business and the compliant costs on business. What is that all about? It is about allowing business to get on with the business of employing Australians. There is only one real answer to lowering unemployment, and that is getting an internationally competitive business sector in Australia. That is how you create sustainable jobs. The way you do that is by reducing the tax burden on business, and that is what our plan does.

Labor ran around during the election campaign saying, `We have a target of five per cent unemployment.' Where was the substance? They did not have one policy that would have resulted in a reduction in unemployment. We do. We have a tax plan which will take the burden off business and enable business to create jobs. Our plan will take $10 billion off the cost of doing business in this country, and that must lead to the capacity to create more jobs. It will also take $4½ billion off the cost of Australian exports.

You run around saying that you are all for helping business, helping manufacturing and helping exports. But, when it comes to the crunch, you are going to come in here and vote against a tax plan that will take $10 billion off the cost of doing business in this country. We are not saying it is a panacea. But it has to mean that business will have a capacity to create more jobs, particularly in the context of our plans for further economic reform and further liberalisation of industrial relations. We are on about helping business create jobs; you want to stop them creating jobs. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Advertising Campaign—Advance to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration. Is the minister aware that the Advance to the Minister for Finance and Administration is only for urgent purposes and is only to be available after the last day for inclusion in the appropriation bills? How can the $10 million of expenditure on the GST ad campaign, decided on by the government a full month before the budget papers were closed, be in any way unforeseen when the government foresaw the need on 7 April 1998? And how can this expenditure be seen in any way as urgent, when the first, relatively small draw-down was not requested until 14 May, after budget night, and the first substantial draw-down was not requested until 10 July 1998?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —There has been a complete review of this situation. As we all know the Auditor-General, through his office, has found that there has been no illegal or unethical behaviour by the government or by public servants in relation to this whole exercise. As a result of that inquiry, the ANAO suggested three areas for review: government information and advertising arrangements; legislative provisions and guidelines governing the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance and Administration for contentious or sensitive matters; and guidelines which specifically address the licensing of copyright to Commonwealth developed material for party political purposes during an election period.

answer.para: The government has looked at that and considers that these reviews are not necessary because firstly, on the current evidence, the government information and advertising arrangements proved adequate to the task; secondly, the ANAO found that the framework and administration of the AMFA was appropriate; and, finally, the copyright guidelines mentioned are under continual review and it is not considered that specific amendments are necessary. So there has been a complete review of this matter by the ANAO, and the government has been totally cleared.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I thank you for that answer. Isn't this government's blatant misuse of the AMFA highlighted by the fact that the decision on 7 April was not just that $10 million of taxpayers' money would be spent on political advertising but that it would be channelled via the Advance to the Minister for Finance and Administration? How can the government justify deciding to spend some money at an undefined time in the future using a mechanism specifically designed for urgent and unforeseen purposes, such as natural disasters?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I covered that point in my previous answer. The AMFA was one of the aspects looked at by the ANAO, and the government was cleared on that point.

—My question is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. I refer to the current climate change negotiations in Buenos Aires. Is it the case that your government, having disgraced Australia at Kyoto by negotiating to actually increase greenhouse gas emissions by eight per cent by the year 2000, has broken even this promise and we are already at nine per cent this year? Is it correct that your government is doing nothing to stop the states heavily investing in more fossil fuel energy production? Is Australia now supporting special consideration for the heavily polluting magnesium plant in Iceland just so that we can get exemptions for more pollution from the likes of the shale oil mine on the coast of Queensland? Finally, is it correct that your government's aim at Buenos Aires is to look for as many escape clauses and loopholes as possible?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: —I will answer this question by saying that, as you note, we are required to limit the growth in our greenhouse gas emissions to eight per cent above 1990 levels by 2008-12, and that will be a very significant reduction compared with the expected growth in emissions if we left everything as it is. It means that Australia will be well and truly pulling its weight at an international level. It is the case that achieving an eight per cent target—getting it down to just eight per cent above 1990 levels—is a big challenge for Australia, and one that will require a commitment and action by all levels of government and the community. We are committed to meeting that target. We have recognised our responsibility to translate international efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions into domestic policy. In November 1997, the government announced a four-year $180 million program to help meet Australia's obligations. Our focus over the next year will be on building upon the environmental gains made at Kyoto.

answer.para: The key issues confronting Australia over this period, including at the fourth conference of the parties, which is being held in Buenos Aires where we are more than capably being represented by Senator Hill, include the following: operational details of flexibility measures such as international emissions trading; joint implementation of the clean development mechanism; commitments by key developing countries to reduce their emissions—without the involvement of countries like China and India efforts by developed countries will be ineffective—and methodologies underpinning the assigned national emissions target.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I doubt we are convinced by your argument that the government is committed to meeting the challenge as given by the earlier example of the shale oil mine in Queensland. As the new resources minister, do you understand that thousands of the world's best scientists have concluded that climate change is real and causes deforestation, sea level rises, extreme weather events, huge increases in insurance claims and diseases like cholera, dengue fever, yellow fever and encephalitis? Are you aware that malaria is expected to spread to 60 per cent of the world's population? Is it the case that your government only talks with Australia's heaviest polluters when it comes to forming our position? Do you personally believe that this is a responsible way to conduct negotiations in the face of such dire consequences?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: —It sounds like the end of the world is nigh, by that recitation. We do take the greenhouse challenge seriously. That is why we put so much effort into these international meetings. That is why Senator Hill has devoted so much time and energy, as has the government, to developing its policy on this. It is a policy which is tough. It is going to be tough on Australian business. We want to try to make sure that it does not cost Australians their jobs. We have a profound commitment to ensuring that Australians are able to remain in gainful employment. But this is a big challenge for Australia and for the world, and Australia will play its part.

—My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration. Can the minister confirm that when costing the opposition's policy commitments before the election the Department of Finance on no fewer than 70 occasions indicated that the assumptions were based on suggestions from the minister's office? Can he confirm that, despite the department's official stating that there was `insufficient detail to cost', the government proceeded to erroneously include $2.7 billion in additional funding for HECS? Isn't it also a fact that the restoration of funding for some Working Nation programs also included in the costings was the result of ministerial interference? In the light of this, does the minister still insist that the costing assumptions were entirely the work of the department?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —The costings of ALP policies that were released by the Treasurer and Minister for Finance and Administration on 9 September this year were prepared independently by the Department of Finance and Administration. Allegations made by the opposition that there was some political interference in the preparation of these costings are simply wrong. The DOFA executive minute dated 31 August this year in the foreword of the costings stated:

answer.para: The costings of the proposals have been undertaken in a similar way to any new policy proposal. All costings assumptions have been made by DOFA and in some cases have been made in conjunction with the affected portfolio.
This was an independent costing. There was no political interference.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the department itself has made these claims, what remains of the government's much vaunted `charter of budget honesty'? Was the freedom to flagrantly misrepresent opposition policy commitments a sealed appendix to the document, or simply an afterthought?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —It is worth while noting that only two days before the election Labor submitted most of its policies for costing, whereas the coalition submitted all of its election commitments for costing in a timely fashion. Therein lies the story. There was no political interference in this process.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Family and Community Services. Minister, how will Australian families benefit from the coalition's tax reform package?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Macdonald for the question. If there is one clear divide in social policy in this country it is the silence, effectively, from the ALP on good policy for Australia's families and the big focus on good social policy for Australia's families from the government, including the tax reform policy—but not only the tax reform policy. It is important that Australians are reminded, in the light of the misinformation that has been put about by the opposition, and particularly by Jenny Macklin, as I recall, that families will benefit from tax reform in a number of ways, including a reduction in marginal tax rates and an increase in the tax-free threshold from $5,400 to $6,000. Every family under $50,000 will have a top marginal tax rate of no more than 30 per cent—a huge improvement on existing rates. Eighty-one per cent of the taxpayers of Australia will have a top marginal tax of no more than 30 per cent. That is a huge improvement on existing rates.

answer.para: The existing $1 billion family tax initiative which the government introduced after the 1996 election is going to be expanded upon—and remember, there will be $13 billion worth of tax cuts and $2.4 billion worth of increases in family payments, all that money largely focused on people with families. The family tax initiative will be doubled, with an increase in the tax-free threshold for families with children under the age of five up to $13,000. In fact, they will not be paying tax until their income exceeds $13,000. That is at a cost of more than $2 billion in the year 2000-2001. It means that families will receive an increase in assistance of at least $140 a year, a 70 per cent increase, for each dependent child. Single income families, including sole parents, with a youngest child aged under five will receive an additional $350 a year, also a 70 per cent increase. A family with a youngest child aged between five and 16 will receive an additional $61 a year.

There will be a substantial easing of the income test for family assistance, and an increase in the amount of assistance directed at families with children through an increase in the level of income at which assistance begins to be income tested from the current $24,350 a year for one child to $28,200 a year. There will be a reduction in the income test taper from 50 per cent to 30 per cent for families, and the transition for women to go from home to work will be considerably eased because of that relaxation of the taper. Anybody who understands these matters—ACOSS particularly so—recognises that that change to the family payments system and the taper rate will make that transition very much easier.

In addition, there will be a 30 per cent rebate from private health insurance contributions, once again very important for Australia's families. Just the very establishment of a department of state for family and community services, with the bringing together of programs across several portfolios, demonstrates this government's serious efforts to develop good policy for Australia's families. When you think back to the debacle of Senator Crowley and her International Year of the Family, which did not get going until halfway through the year, you realise that there is a big contrast between the focus of this government and the entire forgetfulness of the previous government. We are about strengthening Australia's families, not just picking up the pieces at the bottom of the cliff.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Alston. Minister, in its next political donations disclosure to the Electoral Commission, will the Liberal Party be accurate and truthful by disclosing the million dollar donations provided by the so-called Business Coalition for Tax Reform and by the Australian taxpayer? Will the Liberal Party disclose the value of the business coalition's tax advertisements on behalf of the Liberal Party's election agenda—said to be between $4 million and $5 million—only a month before the election was called? Will the Liberal Party disclose the full value of the Australian taxpayers generous and compulsory donation to the Liberal Party's cause through blanket advertisements in the days leading up to the Prime Minister's calling of the election? Can the minister confirm the final cost of over $15.8 million?

—Order! Most of that question related to matters that are not within the responsibility of the minister. If there is anything that Senator Alston wishes to say, I will give him the opportunity to do so, but most of it was not appropriate.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —All I can do is agree with you that these are matters for the Liberal Party. But can I simply say that the choice of the business coalition to run advertisements promoting need for changes to the taxation system was not something that was done on behalf of the Liberal Party.

answer.para: I should just remind you of a couple of statistics. Over 13 years in office, Labor spent a total of $675 million on communications; there were more than 350 advertising campaigns between 1989 and 1995; $9 million was spent on Working Nation, $7 million on the superannuation guarantee and $10 million on the superannuation community education campaign. Let us be clear about this: the campaign that was run by the government was an information campaign along the lines of the very sorts of things that Labor turned into an art form.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, as I understand it, the advertisements that were placed were authorised on behalf of the government. If this is the case, does this not lend itself to the fact that it was a government funded advertising campaign for the Liberal Party?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —If Senator Hogg's proposition is that anything that was authorised by the government in terms of an advertising campaign is therefore something for which the political party ought to pick up the tab, then I invite you to write out a cheque for $675 million for the communications expenditure that you spent—the $315.5 million you spent on advertising—between 1991 and 1996.

answer.para: If we are really going to talk about advertising, I think what we want to know is: how could you have made such a monumental mistake in dumping John Singleton? What a disaster. If ever there was something that we cheered on every night, it was your advertising campaign. We are very grateful to Saatchi. We are very grateful to the geniuses like Senator Faulkner who obviously made that decision out of New South Wales. It worked tremendously well from our point of view. Thank you very much.

talk.start.para: —I have a question for the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Macdonald, who I congratulate on his appointment. My question is: will the minister inform the Senate of what is being done to improve services in regional Australia? Will the minister comment on recent decisions by the banks? Will people living in the bush continue to see real improvements in the delivery of services, particularly in banking?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —It is a delight for me to have my first question asked of me by someone like Senator Eggleston, someone who genuinely represents rural and regional Australia. My colleagues opposite would not understand what rural and regional Australia is all about. They obviously have no interest in the bush. Someone like Senator Eggleston, who comes from regional Western Australia, well represents that area, along with my other Western Australian Senate colleagues.

answer.para: It is true that there have been real problems in country Australia in the last decades or so. These problems—the lack of services, the run down of services—of course became very evident in the days of the 13 years of Labor. Services really went backward. This was exacerbated in my own state of Queensland when the Goss Labor government came to power and again cut down services in rural and regional Australia. I think the same has happened in New South Wales under Mr Carr's government. Services to rural and regional New South Wales have plummeted.

talk.start.para: —Order! There are far too many interjections and too much noise in the chamber.

—During Labor's last six years in office, the number of postal outlets fell by 277. But no action was taken by Labor to reverse this. Indeed, despite being in government for 13 years, Labor took no action to make Medicare claims more accessible to people in regional and rural Australia. So there is a real problem in rural and regional Australia caused by the Labor governments around the states.

answer.para: We have some proposals, some policies, to address this real problem. I guess that the proposals we took to the election are the reason why we did so well in rural and regional Australia. I again congratulate Mr Barry Haase, who for the first time, I think, ever has won the huge regional seat of Kalgoorlie for the Liberal Party. Along with Mr Barry Wakelin, Bob Katter, Bruce Scott and Warren Entsch, we now hold all of the seats in rural and inland Australia.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. I think the new and inexperienced minister may well have misled the Senate just a moment ago in his answer, and he might consider withdrawing his statement.
—That is a matter to raise at another time.

—So what are we going to do about the policies we took to the election? We are going to set up some rural transaction centres, a program of $70 million to be funded out of the sale of a further 16 per cent of Telstra. Those rural transaction centres will provide rural and regional people, for perhaps the first time, with fax and phone services; postal services; personal banking and limited business banking, including automatic tellers; and Medicare easy claim—things that we accept as normal in the metropolitan and provincial city areas, but which were denied to those in the bush.

answer.para: So, Senator Eggleston, that is one of the major planks of our platform, one of the things that we will be doing in this term of government. Those regional transaction centres will be available to communities under 3,000 people and there will be about 500 of them, we hope, over the period. I use the example of the Boulia Shire Council, which has actually got into this sort of thing already. We can learn from them and we will work with local government and many organisations in regional Australia.

talk.start.para: —They wouldn't know where that was.

—No-one over there would know where Boulia is and, what is more, they wouldn't care. In Boulia there was a problem because of what Labor did, but they actually got together with a credit union and put this banking facility in the local authority offices. That is just one of the examples of the policies that we have proposed and will implement. (Time expired)

—Madam President, I would like to ask a supplementary question of the minister. Could the minister comment further on improvements in other services such as the provision of media, particularly SBS, telecommunications, distance education and so on in regional areas which have occurred under the Howard government?

—Madam President, on a point of order: I listened with interest to a ruling you gave earlier in question time. I wonder if part of that supposed supplementary question asked by Senator Eggleston was out of order, particularly the part relating to `and so on'.
—`And so on' does not actually add much to it, but Senator Macdonald may wish to comment upon the earlier part of the question.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Madam President, and I again thank Senator Eggleston, because the things he mentioned are facilities and services that have been denied to rural and regional people because of the policies of a Labor government. As Senator Eggleston has mentioned, we will also be extending access to untimed local calls—that is a $150 million program. We will be providing Internet access for people in rural and regional Australia, something that was denied them by Labor but which we will provide through a $36 million project over three years. We will also be extending mobile phone coverage.

answer.para: As Senator Eggleston mentioned, SBS will be going to many places that cannot presently get it. In fact, because of our policies and what Senator Alston is doing in his field, ordinary television services will go to places where there have been holes, black spots, in previous times. So there is a range of issues which will be implemented. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—This is the first opportunity I have had to speak to the Senate of Stuart Rendell's wonderful achievement in winning gold for Australia at the Commonwealth Games in Kuala Lumpur. Stuart, who is a member of the staff of the Economics Legislation Committee, won his medal in the hammer throw with a throw of 74.88 metres.

speech.para: I was particularly pleased not only because he is a member of staff in the Senate but also because he is a Canberra born athlete who grew up with his athletics in the ACT. He displayed athletic talent from an early age, progressing through Little Athletics to win the hammer and be placed second in discus at the Australian Junior Championships. In his spare time he played Australian Rules for Ainslie.

Stuart is now taking part in a season of domestic competition culminating in the Australian Championships in March 1999. His next international competition is the World Championships in Seville, Spain in August 1999, and his ultimate goal is to represent Australia in the 2000 Sydney Olympics.

Honourable senators would be pleased to note that the Department of the Senate, a participating employer in the Olympic Job Opportunity Program, is supporting Stuart in his quest. Under this program, employers assist elite athletes by allowing them to fit working hours around their demanding training and competition schedules. I am sure all honourable senators would wish to join me in congratulating Stuart on his achievement and in wishing him well in competitions and his quest for the Sydney Olympics.

talk.start.para: —I inform the Senate that, on 18 August 1998, I attended the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly in Darwin to present to the Speaker of the Assembly, the Hon. Loraine Braham MLA, the original of the remonstrance presented by the Northern Territory Legislative Council to the President of the Senate in 1962. This presentation was made to mark the 50th anniversary of the establishment of the Northern Territory Legislative Council.

speech.para: The Speaker of the Assembly, Mrs Braham, had suggested that this document be returned to the Territory to mark the occasion. The remonstrance was not formally tabled in the Senate and, therefore, technically was not a document of the Senate. It seemed to me that it was a document, though, that should still be retained and owned by the Senate and I thought it appropriate to return it to the Territory on permanent loan.

I was pleased to participate in this occasion, and it now stands in their hall alongside the other remonstrances presented to this parliament in recent times. I expressed to the Speaker and members of the Legislative Assembly my congratulations to the people of the Territory and my best wishes for their future progress and development. I table a copy of the remonstrance.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Alston) to a question without notice asked by Senator Faulkner today, relating to ministerial responsibility.

If John Howard was serious about his ministerial standards and parliamentary and ministerial accountability, what he would have done today before the parliament commenced its usual business was to have tabled a revised code of ministerial conduct, something he announced he would do in the election campaign. He also would have delivered bipartisan support to a review of the rules surrounding the use of government advertising, and that is something that the Auditor-General has called for. He also would have rejected the tainted vote of Senator Colston. Why? Because Mr Howard and his government desperately need to reassert some standards in the conduct of this soiled and sorry government he leads.

Think of the breach of standards, Madam Deputy President. In 1995 Mr Howard as then opposition leader promised to review the rules surrounding government advertising as soon as he got into government. Of course political amnesia set in for Mr Howard. He and Senator Minchin proceeded to bend the rules so massively with their $17 million advertising rort just before the last election that the Auditor-General is now calling for new rules in this area. That was an unprecedented abuse by Mr Howard and his government and an unprecedented misuse of public money to promote an election policy, not an operating program of government, in that way.

In 1996 Mr Howard tabled a code of conduct allegedly to keep his ministers honest. From that time onwards it was flagrantly disregarded to the point that Senator Parer had to be retrospectively scalped in the beginning of this parliament. The rules, according to Mr Howard, became guidelines, not a death sentence. It was a code that was never enforced. So much for his standards.

Another breach of standards was the decision that Mr Howard made in 1997 to reject the vote of Senator Colston. That was not because of the fraud investigation, according to Mr Howard, but because `he had to assert standards'—standards of government, standards of parliament. But when he saw the GST looking endangered because of the proper decision he was forced to take back in 1997, he ditched that decision, he ditched that approach, in the interests of political expediency. There was no mention of it before or during the election campaign we have just had. That in itself was a most underhand and deceitful way for Mr Howard to deal with this issue.

In the recent election campaign, the Howard government showed the same disregard for principle and convention, this time with regard to caretaker conventions. It was okay to observe them, as we know from question time today, in relation to somewhat more trivial issues, but as soon as the government decided to milk the Victorian gas crisis for political advantage the caretaker conventions were thrown out the window—another very serious breach of standards by this government and this Prime Minister. That is the pattern of John Howard. He is forever espousing standards to all who will listen, always espousing principle and the high moral ground but yielding to political expediency whenever he can, whenever the pressure mounts—rort the system, throw the rule book out the window, breach the conventions standards.

But what does he do it for? His own cheap political gain. This government is a moral vacuum and it is because of Mr Howard and his approach to parliamentary and ministerial standards. The centre of that moral and political vacuum is the Prime Minister himself, Mr Howard. He stands condemned for his continued breach of parliamentary and ministerial standards. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise, too, to speak on this issue. If ever I have heard a case of the pot calling the kettle black, that was it. I want to look at one or two aspects. We have seen the highest standards ever applied by a Prime Minister to ministerial conduct and the conduct in this parliament in this country's history—the highest standards ever applied. You only have to look at those and compare what went on before. In terms of the Labor Party, we only have to go to a report on 10 November this year. It says:

speech.para: `The state government had broken the law by spending more than $3 billion of taxpayers' funds without permission,' New South Wales Auditor-General Tony Harris said today. In an unprecedented move, Mr Harris appeared before the bar of the Upper House to detail his concerns about budget funds being reallocated without parliamentary approval. `It is actually a crime, as I understand the matter,' . . .

Yet we have Senator Faulkner, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, coming in here today laying charges when, in fact, in contrast, what did the Auditor-General do here in dealing with these particular issues? In relation to the Auditor-General's report, the opposition claimed that the government had breached the guidelines. The report makes it clear that the opposition's claims are absolutely false. The government notes that the guidelines were in place under the former Labor government, which had ample opportunity to change them if they considered them inadequate. Why didn't you change them if you now come in here bleating that they are inadequate and not doing the job?

You have to look very closely at yourselves, your own particular performances and how you have conducted yourselves. The Department of Finance and Administration considers that the current arrangements are adequate and appropriate. The government will carefully consider the ANAO report and respond if necessary. How different to the Labor Party's position and approach in New South Wales. If we talk about expenditure in terms of promoting good policy—and I do not believe that a lot of the policy of the previous government was good policy; in fact, it failed, it collapsed—we find that the Keating government spent $315.5 million on advertising and market research over a five-year period from 1991 to 1996.

Contrast that figure with the small amount of money that this government spent on informing the Australian public about the importance of tax reform—tax reform that will deliver enormous benefits to the Australian economy, tax reform that will give us an internationally competitive tax system, tax reform that will take the shackles off export industries in this country.

talk.start.para: —Liberal Party policy.

—I note the interjection from Senator Cook, a West Australian. Two billion dollars of the $4.5 billion savings to export industries will be in our state. You should take note of the savings that will occur there, whether it be through the reductions in excises on fuel or the removal of the wholesale sales tax and all the inherent costs involved.
—Understand economics.
—I understand economics far better than you do, Senator Cook. At least I have been able to run a successful business.
—Order! Senator Crane, would you please address the chair?
—Through you, Madam Chair.
—To me, not through me.

—I think Senator Cook is the last person who ought to talk about understanding economics. Look at the deficit, the black hole, Labor left—$10.3 billion. Senator Cook was a key player in that. He is the last person who should talk about economics.

speech.para: Let us go on to talk a little more about what Labor did in response to the criticisms that Senator Faulkner tried, but failed miserably, to aim at the government today. Labor spent $6.2 million between 1985 and 1987 on its tax reform advertising campaign, which did very little, if anything, to improve our international competitiveness in a taxation sense. The ALP conducted continuous market research with its then official pollster, ANOP. It engaged public relations consultants.

You can run through the list, which is absolutely endless, of the way Labor behaved and the way it spent money. They were Labor's guidelines. We did not change them. As I said at the beginning of my contribution, if ever I have heard a case of the pot calling the kettle black that is just what we have heard. I think it is time that you have a look at yourself and that you speak to your New South Wales colleagues and tell them to get their house in order. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Australia is proudly one of the democracies in the world that has adopted the Westminster system. One of the pillars of the Westminster system is the caretaker provisions—that is, when a government calls an election the government of the country is put in caretaker mode. From then on, the government makes no more decisions to govern the country, and the Public Service manages the show until the people decide who the incoming government will be. If issues arise during a caretaker period that require government decision making, then the government consults with the alternative government and makes a joint decision about what will be done. That is a fundamental pillar of the Westminster system in order to ensure that things are done fairly and properly. It is a tradition of our democracy. It is guaranteed by the Public Service, which is neutral and oversees the operations of the Westminster system.

speech.para: During the last election period, the caretaker provisions were given real purpose. The foreign minister consulted with the opposition about a visitor from the People's Republic of China, who wanted a state visit to Australia. Minister Somlyay conferred with the opposition about a Cocos Islands matter that required government decision. A government decision was required on the MOPS Act. Minister Minchin conferred with the opposition and a position was reached on that.

There was practice during the last election by several ministers to show that they recognise the importance of the caretaker provisions and observe them. But who did not observe them? Which pre-eminent Liberal flouted the Westminster provisions? None other than the Prime Minister. So-called Honest John Howard flouted the Westminster provisions.

talk.start.para: —Senator Cook, would you please refer to the Prime Minister by his correct title?
—Mr John Howard is often referred to popularly as Honest John Howard.
—No, Senator Cook.

—If that is not appropriate speak in this chamber, then I withdraw the word `Honest' and call him plain John Howard. He broke explicitly the Westminster traditions of the caretaker provisions during the election period. It cannot be said that he did not know what he was doing. He is an experienced parliamentarian. He is a lawyer. He is familiar with the constitution. He knows what the arrangements are. What did he do? He took specific government action in the case of the Victorian gas crisis on the eve of the election in order to buy votes.

speech.para: Why do the caretaker provisions exist? To prevent governments using the exchequer to buy votes during an election campaign. That is what Mr Howard did. All he needed to do was pick up the telephone, confer with the Leader of the Opposition and the deal would have been done. Why didn't he want to do that? Because it would have meant that both he and the Leader of the Opposition would have announced relief to Victorians in the gas crisis. He wanted to best the opposition, make a shallow political point, and nothing would stand between him and trying to win a few extra votes—certainly not the traditions of democracy in the Westminster system, certainly not the traditions of democracy in this country.

This underscores a profound point. When it comes to traditions and conventions that make our democracy effective, the Liberals will break them every time. If they see narrow political electoral advantage, they will set aside the tradition that makes our democracies work and go for the votes every time. Look at the performance of the head of the Prime Minister's own department, Mr Max Moore- Wilton. He says that only three heads of department are good enough to retain because other heads of departments do not sell government policies.

Under the Westminster system, public servants are not salesmen for government policies. Now the head of the Prime Minister's department says that a criteria to be a head of a government department is that you have to be able to sell government policies. That is for ministers. That is for politicians. That is not for public servants. This is an effort to politicise the Public Service of Australia and to give public servants the added job of selling government policies, whether they agree with them or not, under pain of dismissal if they do not.

Another tradition that is fundamental to the role of the Public Service—an independent Public Service, a fearless Public Service being swept away by a government determined to politicise the processes of this country to suit its narrow economic gain—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —We see Senator Cook come into the chamber and talk about a caretaker role of government.
—And I am right.

—I can assure Senator Cook that the only type of government that he is ever likely to be involved with again is in his role as part of a caretaker government before we win the next election. I am quite sure that Senator Cook will never be in the position of being in government again.
—This man is from Brian Burke's Labor Party.
—Brian Burke's Labor Party. We first see Senator Faulkner come in here—

speech.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Cook and Senator Campbell, please let Senator Ferguson have the floor.

—We see Senator Faulkner come in here and shed crocodile tears, having finally realised that he will be spending another three years sitting in exactly the same chair that he has been sitting in for the past 2½ years. The chances are that that will not be the last stretch of time that he spends in that chair, unless his party decides that he is not up to it and replaces him with somebody who is. We saw Senator Faulkner's attempts during the election campaign to raise the issue of propriety as to what the government was doing in relation to spending by government and government departments.

speech.para: The Auditor-General gave this government a clean bill of health on every count. The Auditor-General has found that you had no basis at all for raising any of the issues that you raised during the election campaign or since in relation to spending by this government and spending by this department. He gives this government a clean bill of health. That is quite unlike the situation with your Labor colleagues in New South Wales. I note that, apart from you, Madam Deputy President, there are no New South Wales senators in the chamber. That is presumably because the last thing they want to hear in this chamber is a debate about Auditor-General's reports.

As my colleague Senator Crane said only a few minutes ago, the Auditor-General has found that the state government in New South Wales has actually broken the law—not just done something that is without propriety—by spending more than $3 billion of taxpayers' funds without permission. Yet we see opposition senators come into this chamber and suggest that this government has done something that is improper; yet in this case the Auditor-General says that that is simply not so. Look to your Labor colleagues in New South Wales. I can only reiterate what the Auditor-General said: the New South Wales government has actually committed a crime, as he understands the matter, for spending moneys that have not been appropriated by the parliament.

We see Senator Faulkner coming into this chamber shedding crocodile tears. As I said, he will probably do so from that same position for a long time to come, because that is where he is likely to stay—I see Senator Faulkner now entering the chamber—unless his colleagues see fit to replace him.

talk.start.para: —I thought it was Khemlani coming back in.

—I think the less said about Mr Khemlani, the better. Senator Faulkner comes in here and talks about standards but let me say that, having seen what has happened in New South Wales, the only standards that Senator Faulkner knows are double standards.
—What a lie! How long did you practise that for?

—About two minutes, Senator Faulkner. I wrote it down a couple of minutes ago. There it is. Senator Faulkner talks about the standards that should be attributed to this government, when in fact the Auditor-General says that the government has done its job with propriety. Yet the Auditor-General says that what has been done by the New South Wales government—Senator Faulkner's colleagues in the state that he comes from—is actually a crime.

interjection.para: The opposition are coming in here and venting their spleen because they tried very hard during the election campaign—both in their public statements and in their advertising—to misrepresent what this government was presenting to the Australian people. And in fact the Australian people have found them out. They have returned this government. They want sound economic managers to run this country. They want sound economic management. An overwhelming majority of people in the community know that there is a crying need for taxation reform, and that is what this government has promised it will deliver to the Australian electorate.(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The questions that are before us today relate to the performance of this government throughout the election period, which stems from a pattern of behaviour that was developed over the past 2½ years. Throughout this country there is increasing public debate about the role of political ethics in the operation of governments, the role of political morality in the way in which governments function and the uses by incumbent governments of resources to promote their narrow interests, particularly for short-term political advantage. I am afraid that the performance of this government in recent times has once again demonstrated to those that see there is reason for disillusion in the Australian political process that there is good cause for deep concern.

speech.para: In April 1996 the Prime Minister announced that he was going to pledge his government to new sets of standards. He said that there was going to be a higher level of political morality, integrity and accountability. He said that this was the purpose of his so-called key elements of ministerial responsibility.

Over the period of the last government, however, it became blindingly clear to all of us that those high standards, those great claims to moral superiority, meant very little at all. We saw the removal of three chiefs of staff from his own office, largely I think as a measure of their failure to administer effectively the operations of those guidelines. We saw the removal of some seven frontbenchers. We saw a reinterpretation of those guidelines to the point where the Prime Minister said that a conflict of interest was that which could be defined by observation, by actually seeing that a minister was performing his public duties in favour of a particular private interest. That was understood to mean that the Prime Minister had discovered a new theory of government entitled the `hand in the till theory' of government.

What we have seen after this election is that the Prime Minister once again has sought to reinvent himself. He has sought to present himself as a person of greater moral integrity, a man of great compassion; a man who, once again, would provide this country with a higher level of ethical standards.

What we have noticed, however, is that all of those claims were made against a backdrop of an election campaign which highlighted the very opposite in this government's behaviour. We saw the calling of that election in an attempt to prevent proper parliamentary scrutiny of one of the most major changes to the taxation system that a government has ever proposed. We saw the calling of that election after the government had committed $17 million of public funding to an advertising campaign which was clearly partisan in its intent and aimed at supporting the government's claims in that election campaign itself.

We saw the announcement of the blatant bribes to Tasmania: $150 million in support of the Tasmanian branch of the Liberal Party in its election campaign. We saw the commitment of $48 million—a total of $48 million—in public advertising in a whole range of departments, from employment to the environment, across the government. We saw a massive breach of privacy as a result of the government's use of agencies such as Centrelink to send out what was clearly government propaganda in support of its tax measures and in seeking to use the pensioners of this country in such a way as to garner political support for this government.

We saw clear breaches of the conventions of the caretaker period that has been in operation in this country since the Second World War—and, with the exception of 1975, those conventions have been very largely uncontroversial. These are measures that, of course, under Menzies would have been seen as established political practice—and we have seen them go without comment. Although they had no legal standing, they had been accepted by all sides. But under this government, questions on these measures have been raised in such a way as to bring them into political dispute.

We do not see the same sorts of standards as were exercised by Menzies being exercised by this government. Just as we have seen this government turn its back on the great ideological traditions of Deakin and of liberalism in this country, we see now the moral standards of Menzies being abandoned by this Prime Minister. I can understand, therefore, that while there would be many Australians who do feel that this government has abused its political authority, has brought into question its political integrity, has used Public Servants for narrow political purposes—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Sitting here listening to the opposition speakers this afternoon, I am struck by the total hypocrisy of the opposition in the Senate, and particularly of its leader, Senator Faulkner, talking about standards of political conduct. Senator Faulkner would be the most hypocritical person possible to ever make such claims—which I will precede to demonstrate in what I will say.
—Order! Senator Eggleston, would you like to withdraw calling another member an unparliamentary name?
—I withdraw it, if it is unparliamentary—
—It is.

—but people listening to this broadcast can make their own judgment. Let us first of all deal with the issue of Senator Colston. Senator Colston, like all Australians, is entitled to be regarded as innocent until proven guilty.
—Well, why did Howard do it?
—Order! Senator Faulkner, interjections are unruly and outside of your chair they are illegal.

—That is a basic principle of natural law—and I assure you, Senator Faulkner, you will have your answer on this question of the use of Colston's vote in a minute. What Senator Faulkner raised earlier, and has now raised again, is the question of the government using Senator Colston's vote.

speech.para: I would like to just cast the minds of senators back to the last day of the last sitting when the sale of Telstra was under discussion. Many members of the ALP on the opposite side—especially Senator Quirke, as I recall—spent the afternoon in vicious and vindictive attacks on Senator Colston. But then, when it came to the vote and Senator Colston voted with them, they did not reject his vote; they quite happily accepted it and saw the legislation defeated.

Then we go to the Parer affair, so-called, which has been referred to by Senator Faulkner this afternoon. For week upon week the ALP, under Senator Faulkner's leadership, muckraked and sought to find something wrong with what Senator Parer had done with his family financial affairs. They had abso lutely no luck in finding anything at all there. But the ALP mercilessly attacked Senator Parer and his family, even though, as I have said, there was no substance at all found in any allegations of impropriety about Senator Parer and his family. But was there an apology? No, there was not. If that is not a matter which concerns standards, I wonder what is.

Lastly, we have the question of the Baillieu family of Melbourne. Senator Faulkner will remember this, I am sure. When the Natural Heritage Trust Fund issue was raised, Senator Faulkner spent a lot of time viciously attacking the Baillieu family of Melbourne—and one of its members in particular. But, when it was pointed out to Senator Faulkner that the individual concerned had been deceased for 20 or 30 years and could not possibly have held an interest in the company that he was going on about, there was never an apology—never an apology to the Baillieu family of Melbourne, in spite of one of the most disgusting episodes, I am sure, that this Senate has ever witnessed of an attack on an individual. So how Senator Faulkner can possibly talk about standards, I do not know. He certainly is not an example that I would want to quote or follow, having mentioned these three cases.

I would like to turn to the comments of Senators Cook and Carr who talked about the use of government advertising by the Howard government in relation to the taxation package before the election was called. I think the use of government advertising to explain government policy is quite legitimate; and it would seem that the Keating government thought so too, because the Keating government spent $315.5 million on advertising and market research over a five-year period, from 1991 to 1996—and that was government money.

Altogether over their 13-year period the Hawke and Keating governments spent more than $675 million of government money on so-called political advertising for the government, if that is what explaining government policy is. I will give some details of it. There was $9 million spent to promote Working Nation. The campaign ran until the 1996 election was called. There was $7 million spent between 1992 and 1993 on the superan nuation guarantee campaign. There was $10 million spent in 1995 on the superannuation community education campaign. If that does not demonstrate hypocrisy, what does? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—Proceed.

—During his address to the Senate here this afternoon, I was accused by Senator Eggleston of abusing Senator Colston on the last sitting day of the last parliament. I want to make it crystal clear, even though it might put me down in the eyes of my colleagues on this side, that I did not abuse Senator Colston or mention his name or anything to do with him not only on that last day but on any other day I have been in here since September last year. I ask Senator Eggleston to apologise for that. I also ask him to do his homework properly in the future. I apologise to my colleagues on this side here for taking time on this issue, but the record needs to be set absolutely straight. Plenty of other people may have done it, but I am not yet one of them.

—If what Senator Quirke says is true, I withdraw and apologise. But I do note that he said plenty of other people may have done it. What I heard on that day was vicious, vindictive criticism of Senator Colston.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the Senate Indonesia's continued denial of human rights to the people of East Timor.
Your Petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. actively support all United Nations resolutions and initiatives on East Timor;
2. actively support the right to self-determination of the people of East Timor;
3. work for the immediate release of all Timorese political prisoners;
4. repeal the Timor Gap Treaty; and
5. stop all military cooperation and commercial military activity with Indonesia.

talk.start.para: Senator Bourne(from 343 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows that we citizens of Australia support a world-wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti-personnel land mines.

Your petitioners request that the Senate support our call for a world-wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti-personnel land mines, give high priority to support for efforts to clear land mines in affected countries and use its influence to encourage other countries to financially support the clearance of land mines in poor countries.

talk.start.para: Senator Bartlett(from 1,112 citizens)
Senator Lees(from 510 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:

Australia's old growth forest and wilderness areas are being diminished as a result of continued logging. The Federal Government has granted new woodchip export licenses despite its agreement for a moratorium on logging in high conservation areas.

The statements read as follows—
CHILD SUPPORT LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL
Purpose of the Bill

The purpose of the Bill is to bring about reform of the Child Support Scheme through a series of amendments to the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 and the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988. The major provisions in the Bill will be to:
. include a wider range of income when assessing how much child support should be paid and also using, wherever possible, more up to date income information in assessments;

. allow parents to move from the Child Support Agency collection to private collection by agreement at any time and also require parents to undertake private collection where there is a consistent payment record, but providing a safety net if the private payment arrangements subsequently fail;
. allow carers in receipt of social security payments to end a child support assessment where there is a threat of family violence;

. change the assessment process to improve client perceptions of flexibility and equity, by modifying the exempted income and disregarded income figures used in the child support formula, allowing liable parents to apply for a child support assessment, providing for internal review of decisions by the Registrar, allowing parents to verbally notify changes which affect assessments and enhancing the procedures in relation to applications for departure from administrative assessment;
. protect client's right to privacy, by limiting information about dependent children in assessment notices;
. enhance collection arrangements by allowing more flexibility in payments, offsetting debts between parents, and allowing deductions to be made from a payer's social security pension or benefit;

. provide greater certainty in payments of child support by giving effect to a change in circumstances only from the date notified, allowing payments to be held temporarily in trust if court action is pending over acceptance of application, and providing that the start date of liability for child support is the date of application;

. make arrangements for direct payments in lieu of child support more flexible, allowing payers more choice in the form in which child support is paid by them while protecting payees and meeting the basic needs for children;

. ensure all parents contribute to the financial support of their children by introducing a minimum annual payment of $260 and recognise the cost of second families by changing the family payment income test for payers with subsequent families;

. change the effect of care arrangements or assessments by extending the major substantial care provisions in assessments where parents agree, basing assessments on both factual and lawful care of the child, treating a step child as a relevant dependent child if a court has ordered a duty to maintain, extending child support to the end of the school year for a child who turns 18; and
. allow the Registrar to reject an income estimate which he considers inaccurate and extend the latest date an income estimate can be lodged from 30 June to 31 July.

para.inline: Reasons for the urgency requiring introduction and passage of the Bill

speech.para: The Bill will give effect to major reforms which the Government announced on 30 September 1997 to improve the Child Support Scheme's flexibility, to provide greater equity and to ensure more regular financial support for children.

Delays in introduction of the proposed amendments may mean the loss of some of the benefits to be gained from the reforms. All but three of the amendments were initially to have a commencement day of 1 July 1998. The remaining amendments were to commence from 1 January 1999 or 1 July 1999. The Child Support Agency will begin issuing assessments for the 1999-2000 child support year from March-April 1999. Many of the reforms impact significantly on the assessments that will issue. It is essential, therefore, that the Bill receives early passage to ensure that, if Parliament amends any of its provisions, the Child Support Agency is able to give adequate notice to all affected clients of possible changes to amounts payable prior to the commencement date of the legislation.

para.inline: Result if the proposed Bills are not dealt with in the Autumn Sittings:

speech.para: Delay in introduction of the Bill is likely to attract criticism of the Government. Delays in issuing assessments to clients cause anxiety and uncertainty for clients and will mean that different legislative requirements apply to different parts of the child support year. This will mean considerable confusion to clients every time there is a change in their circumstances causing a variation to their assessment.
STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY SCHOOL EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL

The purpose of the proposed bill is to seek changes to the State Grants (Primary and Secondary Educa tion Assistance) Act 1996 (the Act) to provide funding for the introduction of Full Service Schools and the extension of funding for the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools (NALSAS) strategy, both of which were announced in the Budget.

It is also necessary to include funding amounts for the Capital Grants Programme for 2001 to 2003. Capital funding is approved up to 2 years ahead of the current programme year. The Act contains a footnote stating that the amounts for the years after 2000 will be inserted by later amending Acts as these figures become available. The figures for the Capital Grants Programme for 2001 to 2003 are now available. Insertion of these figures into the Act is essential to finalise schools' planning of capital projects in 2001.

There are also a number of non-controversial amendments to the Act which have been consolidated in this Bill. The first is an amendment which will allow the Minister to vary funding allocations provided to State and Territory government and non-government education authorities under the Commonwealth's Literacy and Country Areas programmes so that 1996 Census data can be taken into account when allocating 1999 funding on a needs basis. Education authorities are expecting this change to occur.

A further amendment will allow for the updating of all funding amounts shown in the Act from 1997 initial prices to 1998 final prices. Unless this is done, funding amounts for Full Service Schools, NALSAS, and the Capital Grants Programme for 2001 will be on a different cost basis. It will also incorporate the effect of 1997 and 1998 supplementation and will mean that all funding amounts in the Act have been calculated on a consistent basis and are comparable.

Finally, there is a technical amendment to section 72(1)(a) of the Act to add the words "or in connection with" in regard to special education funding of non-government centres to allow the full range of special education services to be provided under the legislation. These words were inadvertently omitted in the drafting of the Act.

If the Bill is not dealt with in the Spring sitting the implementation of Full Service Schools will be seriously delayed, expenditure on the NALSAS strategy will be disrupted and the Capital Grants Programme will be unable to commit funding to approved projects with building stages in 2001.

The Full Service Schools initiative will provide additional support to schools to develop innovative programmes and services which address the specific needs of young people returning to school following changes to the Youth Allowance and of current students who are at risk of not completing Year 12 or not making a successful transition from school to work. Delay in passage of the amendment could have an adverse impact on eligible young people.

It is highly desirable that the NALSAS strategy continue with minimal disruption. The delay in the passing of the Bill has meant that additional funding included for 1998 in the original Bill will instead be allocated to 1999 in the current Bill. Hence 1998 funding has decreased by 40 per cent rather than being maintained at 1997 levels. Currently legislated funding ceases at the end of 1998.
HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 1)
The proposed bill will amend the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 (HEFA) to:
. legislate the funding levels in respect of sections 17, 20(3), 22A(5), 23C(2), 24(3) and 27A(6) or the HEFA for the 1998, 1999 and 2000 funding years;
. vary the aggregate funding levels for the 1999 and 2000 funding years to take account of price movements and to facilitate the transfer of funds from the 1997 to the 1998 financial year;

. reduce funding limits for 1998, 1999 and 2000 to allow the use of those funds for international marketing and promotion of Australian education and training services by Australian Education International;
. allow for the provision of funding for the University of Notre Dame Australia while ensuring that full fee paying students may still enrol and are not liable for HECS;
. allow for the provision of additional funding for the James Cook University of North Queensland;
. facilitate the transfer of funding from the 1998 and 2000 funding years to the 1999 funding year to meet the needs of the Rationalisation and Restructuring Programme

Currently there are no legislated funding levels for 1999 in respect of sections 17, 20(3), 22A(5), 24(3) and 27A(6) of HEFA. The Bill provides this base funding and needs to be enacted before the start of the academic year to allow payments to be made to institutions at the usual times.

para.inline: Effect if the Bill is not dealt with in the Sittings

speech.para: Australian higher education institutions will not receive 1999 funding on time.
AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL
AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY (LICENCE CHARGES) BILL
AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL

The Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Bill (the ARPANS Bill) introduces, for the first time, regulatory controls in respect of all Commonwealth radiation and nuclear activities by prohibiting Commonwealth entities from dealing with radioactive materials or apparatus, or any aspect of a nuclear or other prescribed facility, unless licensed to do so.

The ARPANS Bill establishes a system of licensing and exemptions and provides for enforcement of the legislation through the appointment of inspectors with enforcement powers. A statutory officer, the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency (ARPANSA) is responsible for overseeing the regulation of Commonwealth entities including the assessment and granting of licences, monitoring compliance and enforcement of the legislation.
The CEO is also responsible for:
. promoting national uniformity of radiation protection and nuclear safety across all jurisdictions;
. providing advice on radiation protection and nuclear safety issues; and
. undertaking research and services in relation to radiation protection and nuclear safety

The ARPANS Bill also provides for the establishment of the Radiation Health and Safety Advisory Council (RHSAC) to provide expert advice to the CEO on a range of issues including emerging radiation protection and nuclear safety issues, matters of concern to the community, and the adoption of codes of practice and standards. The Council will be appointed by the Minister for Health and Family Services and will comprise State-Territory radiation control officers, a community representative and other experts in radiation and nuclear safety and related fields.

The ARPANS Bill is accompanied by the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety (Licence Charges) Bill (the Licence Charges Bill) and the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety (Consequential Amendments) Bill (Consequential Amendments Bill).
The Licence Charges Bill provides for the levying of an annual charge on the holders of a source or facility licence, as described in the ARPANS Bill.
The Consequential Amendments Bill:

. repeals the provisions of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Act 1987 which create the Nuclear Safety Bureau. The Bureau will become part of the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency (ARPANSA) which is referenced in the ARPANS Bill;
. transfers the assets and liabilities of the Nuclear Safety Bureau to ARPANSA;
. repeals the Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act 1998. That Act provides for the development and endorsement of Codes of Practice which will be undertaken under the auspices of ARPANSA;
. provides that Commonwealth entities have a transition period of 6 months after the ARPANS legislation commences to apply for a licence to authorise specified activities under the legislation.

para.inline: The reasons for the urgency requiring introduction and passage in the same sittings:

speech.para: This legislation was seen as time critical when the Government introduced it in May this year. The Government intended that the legislation take effect from 1 July 1998 to enable appropriate regulation of significant radiation and nuclear activity. The Bills were passed by the House of Representatives.
There continues to be an urgent need for this legislation to be passed as soon as possible for the following reasons:

. Preliminary work on the new Lucas Heights nuclear reactor is proceeding in the absence of comprehensive regulatory control. This may generate significant community concern (ministers will have to take decisions about aspects of the reactor in the absence of the new regulatory framework) and the tendering process to build the reactor will not reflect the health and safety requirements of the new regime.

. The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) has made recommendations about the regulatory processes for a new reactor and stressed the importance of ARPANSA providing comprehensive oversight and having the capacity and sanctions to enforce its decisions.

. The Government decision concerning the siting of Australia's low level radioactive waste repository is scheduled to be made by end 1998, by which time the community and the construction contractors must be assured of independent regulatory oversight.

. Australia is due to sign the Joint Convention on the Safety of Spent Fuel Management and on the Safety of Radioactive Waste Management in November 1998, by which time we need a regulatory process in place which would deliver on our commitments under this convention.
The effect if the Bills are not dealt with in one sitting:
. Signing the Joint Convention on the Safety of Spent Fuel Management and on the Safety of Radioactive Waste Management will be delayed.
. If passage and implementation of the Bills are effectively delayed until mid 1999:
decisions about proceeding with the replacement reactor and the waste repository will have to be taken in the absence of a legislatively established safety framework.
(Circulated with the authority of the Minister for Health and Family Services)
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE 1998 SPRING SITTINGS
STATES GRANTS (GENERAL PURPOSES) AMENDMENT BILL

The States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill will give effect to arrangements for the payment of general revenue assistance in 1998-99, in accordance with the Commonwealth's Offer at the 1998 Premiers' Conference, and revenue replacement payments to the States and Territories in 1998-99.

Commonwealth payments of general revenue assistance and revenue replacement payments are expected to total around $23.5 billion in 1998-99. States and Territories are dependent on these payments to fund essential services so early passage of the Bill will provide greater funding certainty for the States and Territories. If passage is delayed and the Bill is not in operation before December 1998, around $450 million per week would not be paid to the States and Territories.
(Circulated by authority of the Treasurer)

talk.start.para: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

speech.para: That the Senate—
(a) notes:

(i) that a resolution numbered L48 and titled `Towards a nuclear-weapon-free world: the need for a new agenda', will be voted on in the United Nations General Assembly in the week beginning 8 November 1998,

(ii) that the resolution recalls the unanimous conclusion of the International Court of Justice in its 1996 advisory opinion that there exists an obligation to pursue in good faith and bring to a conclusion negotiations leading to nuclear disarmament in all its aspects under strict and effective international control,

(iii) that the resolution calls on the nuclear weapons states to demonstrate an unequivocal commitment to the speedy and total elimination of their respective nuclear weapons and without delay to pursue in good faith and bring to a conclusion negotiations leading to the elimination of these weapons, thereby fulfilling their obligations under Article VI of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT),

(iv) that the resolution also calls on the three states that are nuclear weapons capable and that have not yet acceded to the NPT to clearly and urgently reverse the pursuit of all nuclear weapons development or deployment and to refrain from any actions which could undermine regional and international peace and security and the efforts of the international community towards nuclear disarmament and the prevention of nuclear weapons proliferation,

(v) that the resolution contains a large number of other measures designed to bring about the goal of nuclear disarmament, including a call for the Russian Federation and the United States of America to bring START-II into force without further delay and immediately proceed thereafter with negotiations on START-III with a view to its early conclusion,

(vi) that the resolution incorporates a call for an international conference on nuclear disarmament and nuclear non-proliferation, which would effectively complement efforts being undertaken in other settings and which could facilitate the consolidation of a new agenda for a nuclear-weapon-free world,

(vii) that the resolution is sponsored by Benin, Botswana, Brazil, Cameroon, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Egypt, El Salvador, Guatemala, Ireland, Lesotho, Liberia, Malaysia, Mali, Mexico, New Zealand, Nigeria, Peru, Samoa, Slovenia, Solomon Islands, South Africa, Swaziland, Sweden, Thailand, Togo, Uruguay and Venezuala,
(viii) that the resolution is broadly consistent with the recommendations of the Canberra Commission on the Elimination of Nuclear Weapons, and
(ix) with concern that there are indications that Australia may not vote in favour of resolution L48; and
(b) urges the Australian Government to support this resolution at the United Nations General Assembly.

subdebateinfo.title: Centrelink: Job Losses and Level of Service

talk.start.para: —I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 11 November 1998, from Senator Chris Evans:

interjection.para: Pursuant to standing order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The Government's decision to slash 5,000 jobs from Centrelink and the impact of this decision on Centrelink's levels of service to families, pensioners and the unemployed.'
(Senator for the State of Western Australia)
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times for each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the clerks to set the clock accordingly.
—I move:

speech.para: `That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The Government's decision to slash 5,000 jobs from Centrelink and the impact of this decision on Centrelink's levels of service to families, pensioners and the unemployed.'

It is important that today the Senate debates the issue of the government's moves to slash 5,000 jobs from Centrelink for a number of reasons. This decision impacts on a number of levels.
