talk.start.para: —Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —May I take this opportunity to congratulate you on your election as a senator for the ACT. With the coalition back in government, the opening of parliament yesterday marks a significant period of reform in Australia's history. On 3 October Australians voted for a continuation of the Howard government's sound economic management—management which has kept at bay the Asian economic crisis.

speech.para: During the five-week election campaign I visited 42 seats in New South Wales and the thing that struck me most there was the general recognition of the need for tax reform. Australians voted for tax reform to end the unfair tax burden on middle Australia. They rejected Labor's bandaid approach to tax reform, particularly their retrospective capital gains tax slug, which would have especially penalised Australian family farms.

As a government and as individuals we know the commitments made to our electorates and we are here to honour them to ensure a bold future into the 21st century for all Australians. Despite the knowledge that tax reform is crucial for the future funding of essential social services, the opposition and the Democrats will no doubt attempt to scuttle the government's commitments for no other reason than opposition's sake. Nothing illustrates this clearer than Gareth Evans's letter to Professor Garnett of ANSTO on 11 May of this year, 1998. He wrote:

I am afraid that the realities of politics in an election year, and in particular our need to win Hughes, have led us to a position of opposing a new reactor at the Lucas Heights site—as difficult as that may be to justify in objective safety-focused terms.

And I have to say that he would have to be a dope to write the letter. Just as Labor were prepared to ignore sound advice for political expedience, they will put the nation's economy and the government's ability to provide essential services at risk.

The Democrats will come in here and claim their own mandate. The Democrats' election campaign was arrogant. The inference in their campaign that they or One Nation should control the Senate was arrogant. The Democrats say they could now claim a mandate on the GST with only 8.46 per cent of the vote. That is a misguided conception, particularly in light of a major polling study conducted by the Liberal Party on 3 October which showed that only 13 per cent of people who voted for the Democrats cited the GST as a reason for voting Democrat. I ask the Democrats not to be deceived by their hallucination of a mandate nor use the 1.1 per cent of the voting population to hold the country and its people to ransom.

It is well known that Labor will do whatever it takes to win government. But it did not quite work this time. Over coffee and soft candlelight, Labor promised Cheryl Kernot a sure bet. Too bad if the local electorate did not want her imposed upon them. The Labor Party were lucky with this one, but a fat lot of good it will do them. If her advice as leader of the Democrats to Senator Woodley is any guide—that is, to `stay out of the bush because there are no votes there'—her commitment and understanding of the bush is nil. Labor has written off the bush with the appointment of Cheryl Kernot to her portfolio.

Unlike Labor and their self-confessed uninterested regional spokesperson, our commitment to rural and regional Australia is reflected in a wide range of initiatives, including rural transaction centres, a $3.5 billion initiative in our tax reform plan to slash the cost of fuel and a $70 million boost to the $250 million Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund. The coalition is well aware of the difficulties of the bush and pledges itself to assist the bush through these difficult times.

Labor were not so lucky in New South Wales with their big names. David Hill was doing so poorly in the seat of Hughes against our local Danna Vale that Labor even had to do a deal with One Nation. On polling day I visited the Oyster Bay Primary School to vote and found a man who claimed to represent One Nation handing out material on how to vote for One Nation. Attached to that material was a preference card for David Hill, bearing the name of the New South Wales ALP Secretary, John Della Bosca. When questioned, the One Nation person explained that the two pieces of material were delivered to the booth prepackaged together. Labor professed to take the high moral ground in relation to One Nation and then did dirty deals to get their man over the line. I seek leave to table evidence of Labor's hypocrisy—the material that was prepackaged in a deal with One Nation in strategic booths.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —On the Central Coast, former senator Belinda Neal thought she would try her hand in Robertson. There is no harm in trying, but she need not have bothered. No matter how many maritime unionists poured in there and no matter how much money and time John Della Bosca poured in there, contrary to sound political judgment and much to the distress of the Left in New South Wales, nothing worked. Residents know that Jim Lloyd had delivered many social benefits to the families on the Central Coast and would continue to represent their interests in Canberra.

speech.para: In a similar fashion, Maggie Deahm was a reminder to voters in Macquarie why they voted for Kerry Bartlett in 1996. She was part of the Keating crew who increased their cost of living by increasing taxes when it had promised it would not. They knew what we knew: you cannot trust Labor. Kerry has worked hard for the people of Macquarie and they wanted him to keep on doing it.

The hard work of Jackie Kelly, Ross Cameron, John Fahey, Joanna Gash and Garry Nairn—in conjunction with good local campaigns and a well-managed state campaign—meant that New South Wales held the line.

On behalf of my New South Wales colleagues, I wish to welcome to parliament Bruce Baird, the member for Cook and Alby Schultz, the member for Hume. Both members have an outstanding record of public service and I look forward to working with them to achieve greater things for their electorates and the people of New South Wales.

Unfortunately, some of our Liberal candidates were unsuccessful at the ballot box. The most disappointing results for me personally were the defeats of Bob Baldwin and Robert Lee. Bob, a tireless electorate worker, was always in a difficult position. I wish Bob all the best in his future directions. Robert Lee's fate in Lowe was unfortunately sealed by the ultimate preference betrayal by Paul Zammit.

On behalf of the New South Wales division, I wish to thank the following candidates for their extraordinary campaign efforts: Alan Akhurst, Nahid Aziz, John Coles, Peter Craig, Mathew Cross, Lorna Doona, Tio Faulkner, Alma Freame, Bruce Gatgens, Stephen Iacono, Clive Jensen, James Jordan, David Kibbey, Robert Lee, Scott MacDougall, Cherrilyn McLean, Michael Armani, Charlie Mifsud—and I have to say that Charlie has done a great job since the election down in Wollongong—Peter Monley, Bruce Morrow, David Parker, Joe Rafferty, Maureen Shelley, Gary Sloane and Andrew Thorn. Without them and their small band of loyal workers, the party would not have been able to fly the Liberal flag across the state. The job at times is very difficult and, as a senator and a Liberal, I appreciate immensely the work they put in and the sacrifices they made.

As Chairman of the New South Wales Marginal Seat Committee, I wish to congratulate Michael Osborne, Remo Nogarotto, Mark Connell and their small professional team for their successful campaign. Despite the barrage of Labor campaign funds, the unconditional support of the union movement and Labor's bag of dirty backyard tricks, the division held the Liberal line in New South Wales. On behalf of my parliamentary colleagues and candidates, I wish to express my thanks for their sound strategy, support and patience. I also wish to express my thanks to Lynton Crosby and all at national campaign headquarters.

The New South Wales division is a great team. Thanks must also go to the information unit for providing policy and election information to the public and to the party members who letterboxed, ran street stalls, stood on polling booths and scrutineered. A special thanks must also go to those workers who travelled great distances to support the cause and those who gave up their time in the days following the poll to scrutineer.
Madam President, I look forward to the election of a Collins-led New South Wales government in March.

talk.start.para: —I wanted to also reflect on the recent election campaign. It was during that campaign that the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, wrote in response to a letter which, curiously, was sent to Senator Brownhill, the parliamentary secretary. Apparently Mr Fischer said that he was responding because he had been asked to respond on Senator Brownhill's behalf, which seems somewhat unusual. The response was to a Mr Mazzanti, a member of the South Queensland Pork Action Group. I suppose it is unusual that the Deputy Prime Minister would respond on behalf of a parliamentary secretary, but he is noted for doing unusual things.

speech.para: The letter ran through the usual lines about getting macro-economic settings right and the importance of a free trade regime to the overall wellbeing of the rural community. It also suggested that there are now effective anti-dumping and safeguard procedures to deal with instances where Australian producers for the domestic market are being injured by unfair competition from imports.

He did claim quite inaccurately, I might say, that the opposition's call for action to protect the interests of the pork industry by limiting imports was in contravention of the World Trade Organisation rules. That is not true. He referred to the alleged transport cost savings to rural and regional Australia in the Howard tax plan, but he did not mention the imposition of a $30 billion goods and services tax.
At the bottom of that letter, the Deputy Prime Minister added a postscript. He said:
The pork industry's continuing advertising campaign is very carefully noted, including those elements of the industry pushing it.

Despite the denial from the Deputy Prime Minister's office, this postscript is nothing less than a threat. The impact of One Nation on the Australian political scene and the failure of the Prime Minister to deal with the former member for Oxley at the appropriate time when he had the opportunity has shown up a number of forms.

Firstly, the One Nation Party has brought with it increased racial tension, and there is now increased insecurity in the community. We have also seen the fact that the National Party seems to be in terminal decline. Senator O'Chee and Senator Macdonald will cease to be senators on 1 July next year, leaving the National Party without formal party status in this place.

The presence of One Nation has also driven a number of simplistic policy responses from the government—the most obvious being the decision by the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, to ignore the advice of his minister for primary industries, which was Mr Anderson at the time, and the vast majority of the Australian wool industry to freeze the wool stockpile. Mr Howard has subsequently found that his decision, which was based on Mr Tuckey's and Senator Crane's intervention, was not in fact legally based. Since that decision, we can only describe the current situation as a fiasco.

There is total confusion in the market, which has resulted from Mr Howard's actions, leaving the responsible minister, the industry and the Public Service to try to sort out the mess. In this case, Mr Howard has not acted in the interests of the wool industry but in the interests of a small number of members of the coalition who were terrified of One Nation. He chose not to develop a comprehensive policy response to increasingly difficult industry problems because he preferred a quick political fix. The former primary industries minister, Mr Anderson, tried to get it right, but he was pushed aside in this political exercise.

The pork industry suffered a similar fate. The government did not properly consult, considering the considerable difficulties and circumstances that that industry faced and continues to face. The government did not look at all the possible policy remedies available.

It appears to me that, although there had been a massive surge in imports, although the importers had targeted the peak season for product on the domestic market, although importers had focused on the premium cuts of the product and although there had been a collapse in the price received by Australian producers—a price well below the cost of production—the government dismissed any short-term assistance through the provision of exceptional circumstances. The government also, unfortunately, ignored possible trade remedies, legal remedies, available through the World Trade Organisation.

It was a resolution of this Senate in April this year that pointed the government in the direction of World Trade Organisation safeguard measures—measures the government could draw on to provide some relief for an industry that was clearly under siege, measures that a number of our trading partners, I might add, regularly use. However, the government merely was content to give the industry some money to develop exports. It is my view that, again, it was the threat of One Nation that caused the government to belatedly respond to the pork industry. But, as with the wool stockpile, the government did not respond in an open and comprehensive way. It was not the way you would expect a government to operate.

In a special gazette dated 25 June, the government detailed the general procedures to be followed by the Productivity Commission when investigating possible safeguard action under the World Trade Organisation. Section 16 on page 4 of the gazette states:

A reference can also be made to the Commission for an accelerated report to determine whether critical circumstances exist where delay in applying measures would cause damage which might be difficult to repair.
The Commission will report to the Minister on whether there is clear evidence that increased imports have caused or are threatening to cause serious injury.

This provision is designed clearly to provide immediate but short-term relief to enable a more comprehensive inquiry to proceed, and the industry quite reasonably expects the government to make such an assessment. One would have expected the government to look at all policy options available to deal with the particular issue. There was clearly a crisis, and there was an independent report from the University of Queensland that did identify imports as the major cause of the industry's problem. However, it has become clear that the government has no intention of looking at that option at all.

As required, the Treasurer formally advised the World Trade Organisation of the government's intention to investigate the impact of pig meat imports and the reasons for the inquiry. However, section 3(iii) of that advice stated:
The current investigation is not examining the need for provisional measures.

In other words, we are going to investigate, but we do not think there is a case. The World Trade Organisation's rules say we can investigate the need for short-term help, but we will not apply those rules. We will take up to 140 days to look at this and then we will have our nominee run the process. We will not have the industry nominate a commissioner to sit alongside our nominee, or we will not have an independent chair. That is what the government is saying. The government is saying that we are not prepared to ensure that justice is not only done but also seen to be done, and, I might say, that is the view of the industry. The Australian pork industry at this time feels well and truly dudded by this government process. It feels that the government has failed to respond to genuine industry concerns in a timely manner. When the government finally did act, it acted in a way which was designed to take the pork industry's concerns off the agenda in time for the election.

I am concerned that the results of the Productivity Commission report will reflect, in the end, the government's free trade at all cost bias which has been deliberately built into this process. This industry is not seeking a One Nation style response. It is looking for a comprehensive and legal response to a personal and financial crisis confronting many producers. To date, it has not got that. It quite reasonably took its case to the public during the election campaign. Clearly, the government was very upset with that response.

The postscript on the bottom of Mr Fischer's letter makes it clear that this government intends to make the Australian pork industry pay a political price for its actions. The Australian pork producers are committed to the development of a sustainable, export oriented and jobs generating industry. Unlike the government generally, and the Deputy Prime Minister in particular, we on this side of the chamber are committed to work constructively with them to achieve that goal.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to speak to a submission I have made to the inquiry by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission on LPG cylinder prices in Western Australia and LPG auto gas prices in Western Australia. At the beginning, I seek leave to table my submission to this inquiry.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I thank the Senate. In relation to my submission to the ACCC inquiry into LPG gas prices in Western Australia, I am concerned about the role the Western Australian government has played in the prices that Western Australian consumers pay for LPG gas and bottled gas. Under the Trade Practices Act, it is now possible to prosecute state governments if there is evidence of collusion and, in this case, if there is evidence found of collusion with Wesfarmers Kleenheat in keeping LPG prices unnecessarily high in Western Australia.

speech.para: I am concerned if the Western Australian government has either deliberately colluded with or tacitly approved of Wesfarmers Kleenheat's substantial monopoly market power over the supply and sale of LPG in Western Australia. There was a trust given to the West Australian government and to the people of Western Australia to look at the price of the gas as produced by Wesfarmers Kleenheat and the other market players and the ability of Wesfarmers Kleenheat to domi nate WA's LPG market at the expense of Western Australian consumers causing LPG prices for both cylinder and auto gas to be, in some cases, two to three times higher than in Victoria.

I believe the West Australian government has failed to honour an agreement made in 1994 where the Prices Surveillance Authority agreed to lift the mandating of prices if the West Australian government and producers increased the supply of LPG auto gas and cylinder gas. The Prices Surveillance Authority lifted the mandate, but the government sat on its hands and now they could, under the law, be taken to court and prosecuted because of that. This inaction by the West Australian energy minister and the West Australian government has not been warranted and has been clearly against the public interest. There is no capital barrier to enter the LPG market.

There have been six different partners in the North West Shelf to chose from. LPG could be shipped to Fremantle from any of these six partners or from LPG suppliers overseas. These North West Shelf partners will shortly decide to almost double the volume of LPG produced after the year 2000 to almost two million tonnes per year. Woodside Petroleum actually told me that they would be prepared to sell and ship LPG to wholesalers in Perth and into Western Australia's domestic markets.

Not only has the West Australian government failed to look after consumers, but they failed to provide environmental leadership for the whole community. By increasing suppliers and keeping the prices down, the West Australian government could create an economic incentive for heavier diesel powered vehicle owners to change to gas. Heavier vehicles produce 70 per cent of the total vehicle pollution and alternative fuels like LPG and CNG could cut these emissions by over 50 per cent.

There is now growing scientific evidence of increased cancer risks, asthma, respiratory ailments and an increased death rate from diesel fumes. Perth already suffers from haze alerts and temperature inversion of the atmosphere between the hills and the coast. The example that has been given from Kyoto University in Japan has found diesel has one of the most carcinogenic compounds ever detected, a substance called nitrobenzathrone. A study of diesel bus drivers in Copenhagen has found 60 per cent higher lung and 40 per cent higher bladder cancer rates amongst those drivers.

I believe the West Australian energy minister has turned his back on the people of Western Australia when he could have made a real difference to the quality of the air they breathe. I believe these issues are important. I believe it is very important that the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission has the full information it needs for this inquiry. I will be keeping a very close eye on the outcome and making sure that we can get better outcomes for consumers, for the environment and for small business in a win-win situation in Western Australia.

talk.start.para: —I want to make some comments tonight about the pork industry and correct some of the views expressed by Senator O'Brien earlier. The pig meat industry is very important to all of us who live in regional Australia. The government is very aware of the pain that is being felt by many producer families. The government and the pork industry are working in partnership to improve the pork industry's international competitiveness.

speech.para: The government Pork Industry Restructure Strategy is based on outcomes from a number of strategic studies. It includes a $19 million integrated package of grant programs to assist individual enterprises and groups to achieve a strong market focus and improve their international competitiveness in the global food market. The $19 million pork industry adjustment package comprises the $10 million National Pork Industry Development Program, which can fund projects ranging from market research to skills acquisition, the $8 million Pigmeat Processing Grants Program, which aims to stimulate investment in the processing sector, and the $1 million that has been provided under FarmBis for a national skills enhancement training initiative for pork producers. Funding approvals under the $10 million National Pork Industry Development Program commenced in July 1998 and to date some $2.8 million has been approved by the government for projects in production, processing and retailing sectors.

There is much more to be done for the pork industry. Some examples of the projects that have been approved include a major domestic market development promotion for fresh pork and bacon—managed by the Australian Pork Corporation and financially supported by the retail industry—and other projects are in the areas of risk management, market development, production and training.

The national pork industry development group is working in close consultation with industry on several initiatives, including driving forward the key elements of their business plan such as export development, the formation of networks alliances and managing a benchmarking study of the pork industry chain. The $8 million Pigmeat Processing Grants Program provides investment grants to eligible specialist pig meat processors to improve the competitiveness of this important sector. The program will stimulate investment in the processing sector by funding up to 10 per cent of the costs associated with new plant and equipment with a cap of half a million dollars per company per year over the three-year life of the program.

In addition, Senator O'Brien referred to the referral of the problems of the importation of pig meat to the Productivity Commission. The government announced in June that it would introduce a general safeguard mechanism as part of the recent pig industry assistance program. The Productivity Commission was designated as the appropriate domestic agency to conduct inquiries and report on whether safeguard action, in accordance with the World Trade Organisation agreement on safeguards, is warranted against imports of certain frozen pig meat, predominantly that from Canada.

This is the first safeguards inquiry undertaken by Australia under the new rules that came into operation in 1995. Safeguard measures provide temporary assistance and an opportunity to adjust for an industry suffering serious injury or threatened by serious injury as a result of increased imports. The Productivity Commission will also report on factors affecting the profitability and competitiveness of domestic pig farming and pork processing industries.

Professor Richard Snape, the inquiry's commissioner, has implemented a transparent process with regular updates on progress being available to interested people. The reporting deadline is this Friday, 13 November 1998. That date was set by the Treasurer. The report will be published and made available in due course.

The Productivity Commission will determine whether there has been serious injury and the remedy that is appropriate. The remedy also has to be in the public interest before a recommendation as to what safeguard can be applied. The inquiry process and remedy is governed, as I said, by the World Trade Organisation rules, and the Canadian pork industry has taken a keen interest in the inquiry, as well they might.

Staff from the department met with Professor Snape on 4 August 1998, and the department outlined the flexibility on variables impacting on the industry's current situation—the government's $19 million integrated package of business assistance programs, RASAC's decision and the range of welfare assistance measures presently available and those also available under the AAA package. During these meetings, Professor Snape indicated an appreciation of the government's interest in releasing the inquiry's findings quickly. I look forward to the commissioner's ruling on whether safeguard action is warranted and the commissioner's finding in relation to the factors affecting the profitability of this very important Australian industry.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 11 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Are the Australian Research Council (ARC) and the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) the major funding bodies for science research in Australia.
(2) How many applications were received for the last round of awarded ARC grants.
(3) How many applications were received for the last round of awarded NHMRC grants.
(4) How many of the ARC applications were successful.
(5) How many of the NHMRC applications were successful.
(6) Are there ARC applications which are worthy of funding, but did not receive funding.
(7) Are there NHMRC applications which are worthy of funding, but did not receive funding.
(8) How many worthy ARC applications were unsuccessful.
(9) How many worthy NHMRC applications were unsuccessful.
(10) Why were worthy ARC applications not funded.
(11) Why were worthy NHMRC applications not funded.
(12) How much extra money would be needed to fund the worthy ARC applications.
(13) How much extra money would be needed to fund the worthy NHMRC applications.
(14) How much is an FA18 fighter worth.
(15) How much is a Leopard tank worth.
(16) What is the Commonwealth's budget for the sports.
(17) What is the Commonwealth's budget for the arts.
(18) What is the Commonwealth's budget for health.
(19) What measures is the Government taking to increase the funding for science research.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The following ministers have provided answers to the honourable senator's questions:

answer.para: (1) The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has provided the following answer:

This is a matter of how "science research" is defined and what may be assessed as "major". Section 3 of the Science and Technology Budget Statement 1997-98 provides information on relevant funding provided through a number of Commonwealth programs and the senator may wish to refer to that publication.
The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer:
Yes, they are major funding bodies.
(2) The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer:
3,284 applications were received in the round for funding of 1998 Large Research Grants.
(3) The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer:
In 1997 1,577 NHMRC project grant applications were received for grants to be awarded in 1998.
(4) The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer:
658 applications were approved for funding under the Large Grants Scheme. Funding was also provided for 8 Special Investigator Awards.
(5) The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer:
Of the number at (3) above, 413 NHMRC project grant applications were successful.
(6) The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer:

As the premier research grants scheme in the higher education sector, the DEETYA/ARC Large Research Grants Scheme is highly competitive. Large Research Grants are awarded to applications which are most worthy of funding in that they meet the highest standards of excellence in terms of the proposal and the track record of the researcher as determined by an external peer review process. There are many applications received that are considered to merit external peer review.
In the last granting round of the Large Research Grants Scheme, 658 of the 2,394 applications considered to merit external peer review were awarded grants.
(7) The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer:
Funding was provided only to the most worthy applicants.
(8) The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer:
Funding was provided only to the most worthy applications.
(9) The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer:
In 1997 RGICs made recommendation for funding of a total of 954 project grants of which 541 were unsuccessful.
(10) The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer:
The most worthy applicants were funded.
(11) The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer:

The NHMRC allocates funding for a range of grants from the health research appropriation. In 1998 $99.7 million has been allocated for competitive project grants. Each year about 67 per cent of the project grant allocation is required for ongoing project grants (in 1998 $66.8 million) and the rest is available for allocation to new grants (1998 $32.9 million). The highest ranked applications are funded within the limits of the available funding.
(12) The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer:
(13) The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer:
(14) The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer:
The average current asset value of a F/A-18 aircraft is $32,907,000.00
(15) The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer:
The average current asset value of a Leopard ASI gun tank is $800,000.00.
(16) The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has provided the following answer:
This information is available in the 1997-98 Commonwealth Budget Papers which are publicly available.
(17) The Minister for Communication and the Arts has provided the following answer:
The Commonwealth's budget for the arts as indicated in the "Portfolio Additional Estimates Statements 1997-98", Program 1.1 Arts and Heritage Policy is $289,418,000.
(18) The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer:
The latest available published figure for Commonwealth outlays on the health function for 1997-98 is $20.787 billion (source—'Mid-Year Fiscal and Economic Outlook 1997-98" statement).
(19) The Minister for Industry Science and Tourism has provided the following answer:

This financial year Australia will invest around $7.5 billion on science and technology through government programs and spending by Australian business. The Government alone will spend about $3.3 billion on science and technology this year.
Australia ranks fifth in the OECD in terms of R&D expenditure in government agencies and universities measured as a percentage of GDP.
The Government has maintained funding for public sector research while addressing the budget deficit. In 1997-98 funding for the CSIRO increased in real terms.

Funding for the science authorities, the CSIRO, the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) and the Australian Institute of Marine Science was agreed through to the year 2000 in the 1996/97 budget. This has restored stability to the funding base of the science agencies. These organisations are now able to set priorities, properly plan their research programs and ensure that specialist skills are available.
A major upgrade to Australia's nuclear science infrastructure was announced by the Government in 1997 with the decision to invest $286 million in a replacement for ANSTO's research reactor.

The Government has introduced a number of measures to stimulate business R&D such as R&D Start which received an additional $556 million in funding in the 1997 Industry Statement Investing in Growth, bring total funding to $739 million over four years. These measures compliment the 125 per cent Tax concession which has been reformed to ensure that it achieves its intended objective.

The Government is improving links between public sector researchers, business and other research users and between Australia and the international scientific community such as announcing the $72 million Technology Diffusion Program which will be directed towards technology diffusion activities over the next four years.

The Government has established the Innovation Investment Fund which is designed to greatly assist the commercialisation of research outcomes in Australia. Together with private sector funding the $173 million provided by the Government for this Program will create an overall investment pool of $260 million.

Complementing this initiative, in the recent Greenhouse Statement, the Government committed $61 million in venture capital, loans and grants for development and commercialisation of renewable energy technology. This will directly support the creation of new business, jobs and exports in high growth industries of the future.
The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided input to the following answer:

(19) The Government remains committed to providing support for science research undertaken in the higher education system. As a measure of this commitment, through the Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs portfolio, the Government announced additional support in the Higher Education Budget Statement 1996, totalling $132.5 million in 1997, 1998 and 1999 for targeted higher education research (in 1998 outturn prices). This increased support included an additional $92.8 million for research infrastructure, $30.1 million for industry/university collaborative research grants, though the Strategic Partnerships—Industry Research and Training Scheme (SPIRT), and $9.6 million for Australian Postgraduate Awards.

The Government's Investing for Growth statement provided funding for a further 50 Australian Postgraduate Awards (Industry) (APA(I)), as part of SPIRT, in each of 1999, 2000 and 2001 at a cost of $9.2 million. These APA(I)s will enhance university-industry linkages in information technology related areas.

Further measures to increase research funding through the portfolio, including for science, in subsequent years will be considered in the context of the 1999-2000 Budget and as the Government develops its response to the recent Review of Higher Education Financing and Policy (the West Review).

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Federal Police: Truce Monitoring Group Duties
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1217)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 25 June 1998:

question.para: (1) What type of work have Australian Federal Police officers been required to undertake whilst being part of the Truce Monitoring Group.
(2) (a) Have these police officers been involved in any policing duties or police training duties; and (b) were they in uniform; if not, why not.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —The answer to Senator Quirke's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Initially AFP officers were deployed as truce monitors. Following the signing of the Lincoln Agreement on 30 April 1998 the AFP officers were deployed as peace monitors.
- to observe and monitor that the Burnham Truce is being maintained by all the Parties;
- to report alleged breaches of the Truce;
- to liaise with local truce monitoring committees;
- to facilitate the peace process by setting an example, explaining the truce, and the peoples' obligation to it; and
- by its presence, discourage potential breaches of the truce.
- monitor and report on compliance with all aspects of the ceasefire;
- promote and instil confidence in the peace process through its presence, good offices and interaction with the people in Bougainville;

- provide such assistance in implementation of the Lincoln Agreement as the parties to the Agreement and the States contributing to the Peace Monitoring Group may agree and available resources allow; and
- cooperate by agreement in ways that assist in democratic resolution of the situation.

(2) (a) No. Policing duties were performed by the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary. (b) No. The AFP officers wore the same clothing as other Australian monitors under the terms of engagement for the Truce Monitoring Group.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Federal Police: Truce Monitoring Group Staff Selection Process
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1218)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 25 June 1998:

question.para: (1) What selection processes were utilised by the Australian Federal Police (AFP) to select the police officers deployed to the Truce Monitoring Group.
(2) What are the lengths of their tours of duty to the island.
(3) What is the intention of the Government in regards to future AFP deployment.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —The answer to Senator Quirke's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) AFP officers were selected on the basis of merit taking into consideration past United Nations involvement, availability and the impact the release of the officer would have on AFP operational requirements.

(3) AFP involvement on the island is constantly under review. The question of Australian commitment to the Bougainville peace process will be addressed shortly in the lead up to the election of an interim Transitional Government.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Federal Police: Truce Monitoring Group Terms and Conditions
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1219)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 25 June 1998:

question.para: (1) What administrative arrangement exists which covers the police officers' terms and conditions while part of the Truce Monitoring Group (TMG).
(2) Is it a fact that police deployed to the TMG were nominally required to work only 38 hours per week between the hours of 7am and 6pm Monday to Friday.
(3) Is it a fact that the police in reality, routinely worked outside these hour without any additional financial remuneration for those duties.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —The answer to Senator Quirke's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) AFP police officers serving as part of the Truce Monitoring Group are covered by a Commissioner of Police Determination made under section 30 of the AFP Act 1979. Such Determinations are required to be consistent with Government wages policy and a copy was provided to the officers prior to their departure for Bougainville.
(2) Yes. These are the normal hours of duty for all AFP members.

(3) No. The AFP members of the contingent who worked in excess of 3 8 hours per week, were compensated by the payment of a 40% composite allowance. In the case of those members in Bougainville directed to work shift work consistent with the Determination, normal shift allowances have also been paid. AFP members in Bougainville also received a range of other allowances, including a Bougainville Allowance of $10,371 per annum, and Mission Allowance of $16 per day.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Federal Police: Truce Monitoring Group Terms and Conditions
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1220)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 25 June 1998:

question.para: Was the Truce Monitoring Group commander made aware of the limitations placed upon police officers in regards to their hours of duty; if so, when, if not, why not.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —The answer to Senator Quirke's question is as follows:

answer.para: No. See response to question 1219. AFP officers were deployed to Bougainville on a normal 38 hour week with appropriate remuneration paid for hours worked outside these hours. Where it was necessary for AFP officers to perform duty outside of normal shifts the approval of the Truce Monitoring Commander, or his delegate, was necessary. This requirement was stipulated in the Commissioner of Police Determination promulgated specifically for service in Bougainville.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Federal Police: Truce Monitoring Group Funding
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1221)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 25 June 1998:

question.para: (1) Did the Australian Federal Police receive supplementary funding for the deployment of officers as part of the Truce Monitoring Group from any other agency or private body.
(2) Did any such funding cover items such as overtime and penalty payments; if so, how much funding was delivered.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —The answer to Senator Quirke's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. During 1997—98 the AFP received $31 960 from AusAid to assist with the first deployment of AFP officers. The AFP anticipates further funding will be provided during 1998-99 to assist with the costs of additional AFP officers deployed to the Truce Monitoring Group.

(2) Funding provided to the AFP by AusAid was not specifically allocated by AusAid to overtime and penalty payments. The level of funding was based on a formula approved by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and provided $120 per day per officer and a one-off equipment allowance of $430 per officer. The funding provided in this manner does not cover the total cost incurred by the AFP in providing officers to the Truce Monitoring Group.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 8 July 1998:

question.para: (1) What percentage of Chinese students using student visas return to China when their visa expires.
(2) What percentage of Chinese students are granted a variation to their student visas and what are the sub-categories of these.
(3) What percentage of Chinese students overstay their visas.
(4) What percentage of Chinese students overstay their visas for: (a) more than a month; (b) more than 6 months; and (c) more than 12 months.
(5) What percentage of Chinese business visa holders overstay.
(6) What percentage of Chinese business visa holders change the status of their visas.
(7) What percentage of visitors from China who come to Australia as part of a delegation overstay their visas.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Of the 1754 students from the People's Republic of China (PRC) who arrived in program year 1995-96 (students from the Hong Kong Self Autonomous Region are excluded from any of these figures), 45% departed Australia upon expiry of their initial student visa.
(2) 24% of the 1754 PRC students were granted a different class of visa. Of these:
. 21.6% were granted a permanent residence visa on family relationship grounds;
. 0.5% were granted a permanent residence visa on skilled grounds;
. 0.3% were granted permanent residence on refugee grounds; and
. 1.6% were granted a temporary entry visa other than a student visa.
(3) 5% of the PRC student cohort overstayed and are unlawful, while 26% of the 1754 PRC students remain in Australia on a valid student visa.
(4) The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs does not maintain statistics for the individual periods requested.

(5) Of the 32,800 people from the PRC who entered Australia in program year 1996-97 holding a Subclass 456 Business (short stay) visa, (business visitors from the Hong Kong Self Autonomous Region are excluded from any of these figures), 0.2% were recorded as having departed unlawfully, while 1.9% were recorded as remaining unlawfully in Australia.
(6) Of the 32,800 people from the PRC who entered Australia in program year 1996-97 holding a Subclass 456 visa, 9% changed their status onshore.
(7) The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs does not keep statistics specific to over stayers who came to Australia as part of a delegation.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 23 July 1998:

question.para: (1) (a) When did the Victorian Government first raise the matter of drought exceptional circumstances (DEC) assistance for East Gippsland with the Minister or the department; and (b) how was the matter raised.
(2) (a) When did the Victorian Farmers' Federation first raise the matter with the Minister or the department; and (b) how was the matter raised.
(3) (a) When did the Minister receive an application for assistance; and (b) who lodged the application.

(4) Did the Minister or the department seek further information from the Victorian Government or the Victorian Farmers' Federation following the lodgement of the applications; if so, when was the request made and when was the information provided.

(5) (a) When was the matter referred to the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Committee (RASAC); (b) when did RASAC report to the Minister on the matter; and (c) when did the Minister take a submission to Cabinet in support of the application.
(6)How many people have so far applied for assistance through DEC.
(7) (a) How many people are in receipt of benefits; (b) many people are currently being assessed; and (c) how many people have been refused assistance.
(8) (a) How many people are in receipt of: (a) an interest rate subsidy; (b) an exceptional circumstances relief payment; (c) special access to health care card and family payments; and (d) Austudy.
(9) What is the basis for rejection of some applications for assistance.
(10) What is the average time between an application for assistance being lodged and the assistance being provided.
(11) Is assistance payable for the date that DEC is approved for a region or from the date an application for assistance is lodged
(12) What are the current means and asset test applied to applicants for assistance through DEC.

(13) How has the Minister applied the means test to farmers who were forced to divest themselves of stock as part of the Victorian Government's compulsory Ovine Johnes disease eradication program in early 1997.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) The Victorian Government first raised the matter of a possible DEC application with officers of the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industries and Energy in late 1997. (b) The matter was raised in a telephone conversation.
(2) (a) The Victorian Farmers Federation contacted the Minister on 22 December 1997.
(b) The matter was raised in a letter.
(3) (a) The Minister received the Victorian application for assistance on 5 January 1998.
(b) The application was lodged by the Hon Patrick McNamara, MP, Deputy Premier and Minister for Agriculture and Resources in Victoria.

(4) Further information was sought by the Bureau of Resource Sciences by telephone on 17 February 1998 from the Department of Natural Resources and Environment in Victoria. This additional information was provided on 24 February 1998. Further information was provided by Victoria to officers of the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industries and Energy and to RASAC during the RASAC inspection of the area on 2-3 March 1998.
(5) (a) The matter was referred to RASAC on 22 January 1998;
(b) RASAC reported to the Minister on 24 March 1998.
(c) the Minister took a submission to Cabinet on 30 March 1998 supporting the application.

(6) There have been 289 applications for Rural Adjustment Scheme (RAS) DEC interest rate subsidies in East Gippsland up to 4 August 1998. There have been 558 applications for the Exceptional circumstances Relief Payment (ECRP).
(7) (a) As at 4 August, there are 181 farms in East Gippsland receiving DEC interest rate subsidies and 413 families in receipt of the ECRP.
A total of 844 EC certificates have been issued up to 4 August 1998.
(b) There are 30 applications for DEC interest rate subsidies and 60 ECRP applications currently being assessed.
(c) 78 applicants for DEC interest rate subsidies and 85 ECRP applicants have been refused assistance.
(8) (a) There are 181 farm businesses currently in receipt of DEC interest rate subsidies.
(b) There are 413 farm families currently in receipt of the ECRP.
(c) All farm families in receipt of the ECRP automatically receive a Health Care Card. All ECRP recipients with children are eligible for Family Payments.
(d) Information on the number of rural students taking advantage of the Youth Allowance (formerly Austudy) concession available in EC areas is not yet available.
(9) In relation to DEC interest rate subsidy support, the reasons for rejection were:

entry.para: Future profitability not demonstrated given limited productive capacity & debt level
Either not in need as trading profitably or off-farm assets exceed limit
Either not farmers or less than 75% of labour involved in farming
Debt level too high to demonstrate future profitability
Either outside declared EC area or had irrigation water right

answer.para: The main reasons for rejection of ECRP claims have been:

entry.para: Income, either from farming or non farming sources, precludes entitlement
Not a farmer, generally where farming is not the primary source of income

answer.para: (10) The average time between receipt of an application and approval for DEC interest rate subsidy support is 16 days.

The time between an application for ECRP assistance being lodged and the assistance being provided is usually within the set standard of 28 days. This is dependent on farmers providing all the details required at the time the application is made; in most instances this would be within 14 days. In some circumstances where the standard has not been achieved it has taken time for farmers to provide current income details.

(11) When EC is declared in an area, a "grace" period of approximately 2 months is allowed for ECRP applicants to receive payments backdated to the date of declaration. In the case of East Gippsland, farmers who applied for an EC certificate on or before 31 May 1998 were issued with a certificate valid from the date of declaration (30 March 1998) allowing ECRP payments to be backdated to that date.
In the case of DEC interest rate subsidies, the "anniversary date" from which support is provided is the date on which the application is lodged.

(12) The current means and asset tests applied in the case of DEC interest rate subsidies is contained in the policy guidelines applying to this support. The relevant clause from the guidelines is set out below:
In assessing the eligibility of a farm enterprise for an interest subsidy the State RAS Authority shall be satisfied that:

(a) the farm enterprise is in financial difficulty due to exceptional conditions, referred to in Clause 1(a). In considering whether a farm enterprise is in financial difficulty, the State RAS Authority shall consider the total amount of interest payable per annum, the estimated farm surplus over the medium term, and the applicant's equity in the farm business in relation to the amount of current and future indebtedness, together with both farm and off-farm assets and income
(b) the provision of support under these guidelines is necessary to achieve the strategy as outlined in Clause 1 of these guidelines
(c) without support under these guidelines the farm unit would not have the capacity to achieve or maintain sustainable long-term profitability
(d) in assessing the likelihood of the farm enterprise being profitable in the long-term, the following factors shall be taken into account by the State RAS Authority

(i) the farm is subject to a program of productivity improvement or skills enhancement under normal provisions of the 1992 RAS scheme and/or the farm is able to demonstrate that it has operated without normal RAS support in at least two of the past five years

(ii) the expected future capacity of the farm to operate profitably (without Government support) as measured by its ability to meet, from estimated surpluses, its future financial commitments relating to
(B) living costs of the farm family
(D) future capital requirements for plant and improvements; and
(E) investment requirements to return the farm to profitability
(iii) the long-term economic trends which impact on the farm enterprise
(iv) the demonstrated technical, financial and business management performance of the applicant
(v) the provision of financial support for the farm enterprise by commercial lenders through the exceptional circumstance and beyond; and

(ii) off-farm assets, such that the net value of off-farm assets is not in excess of $178,500 on commercial terms and applied the proceeds to the farm business (except where this would result in extreme hardship to the applicant). Investments in bona fide insurance and superannuation funds are exempt from the off-farm assets test

(f) under normal circumstances, the applicant contributes at least 75 per cent of his/her labour to the farm enterprise, at least 50 per cent of income is derived from farming, and has been a farmer for at least two years
(g) the applicant's property is now affected by exceptional circumstances as defined in Clause 1(a) of these guidelines

(h) loans supplied by a commercial institution, vendor or by private arrangements, are provided on commercial terms at arms length and the interest rate charged by the lender is competitive with that which is generally applicable to the type of loan(s) being subsidised

(i) support will not be available to farms in irrigation districts, other than dryland farms, except for farmers who derive more than 20 per cent of farm production from irrigated agriculture and whose water allocations are 80 per cent or less of their normal water allocations in 1996/97 and 1997/98.
The current means and asset tests applied to the ECRP are:

If a farmer has non farming assets in excess of $125,750 for a single homeowner or $178,500 for a married homeowner no payment is allowed. Where the farmer does not own the home property, the amount of assets allowed is higher but this situation is not common with farmers.

If a person earns income of less than $60 per fortnight, payment is not affected. If the person earns less than $140 per fortnight, the rate is reduced by 50 cents in the dollar for every dollar of income above the $60 free threshold. Any amount earned over $140 in a fortnight reduces the payment by 70 cents in the dollar. This income test is applied to income from all sources, including any estimated farming income that may be earned.

(13) For the purpose of DEC interest rate subsidy assessment, any stock sale proceeds and/or compensation money as a result of Ovine Johnes disease eradication has not been an issue in determining eligibility—ie such funds are not included in any means test.

In calculating the rate of ECRP the Farm Household Support Act 1992 at section 24A allows the proceeds from a forced disposal of livestock to be disregarded when the disposal occurs in the period during which the farmer holds a valid EC certificate and the proceeds are deposited as required by the Act. This means that where a farmer receives the proceeds from the forced disposal of livestock through a disease eradication program during the period the farmer has an EC certificate, those proceeds will not be counted as income when they are deposited as required by the Act.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 August 1998:

question.para: With reference to reports from Bougainville that a young boy was badly injured by a `landmine' which contained ball bearings and was tripped by a cord:
(1) Does the Minister consider that civilian lives are still in great danger from landmines and booby traps on Bougainville which have been set by the Papua New Guinea Defence Force.

(2) Are there any members of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) on Bougainville who have the expertise to dismantle these booby traps and landmines; if not, has any consideration been given to sending ADF personnel with such skills to Bougainville.

(3) Is it possible that these booby traps could be hand grenades manufactured by Australian Defence Industries with the trip wire option attached; if so, what action will the Government take to prevent the use of these insidious weapons that have escaped the ban under the landmines convention on a technicality.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) There is evidence of landmines and booby traps in several areas of Bougainville. All factions involved in the conflict have claimed responsibility for employing these weapons. Thus, a degree of threat to the civilian population remains.

(2) There are presently no ADF personnel on Bougainville who are trained in Explosive Ordnance Disposal. Consideration was given by the Peace Monitoring Group (PMG) to deploy such personnel. However, it was assessed that the presence of explosives did not present a sufficiently serious threat to PMG personnel. No member of the PMG has been injured by a mine or booby trap on Bougainville. Further, the PMG's medical team has neither seen nor treated any local person injured by a mine or booby trap.

(3) During the last eight years, a quantity of smoke or training (non-operational) grenades, practice grenades and practice grenade fuses have been exported to Papua New Guinea (PNG) by Australian industry. However, there is no record of operational grenades, or firing devices demolition, being exported to the PNG Defence Forces (PNGDF) by Australian industry during this time. Given the nature of these items, it is highly unlikely that Australian grenades have been used as booby traps on Bougainville. In 1992, an Australian company did demonstrate its operational grenades to the PNGDF in PNG. However, no sales resulted.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 19 August 1998:

question.para: (1) When provided by a registered medical practitioner, does Medicare refund for (a) ozone therapy; (b) remedial massage; (c) herbal medicine; (d) naturopathy; (e) homoeopathy, (f) chiropractic/osteopathy; (g) acupuncture; and (h) iridology.

(2) Given that (a) various countries set the education gold standard for manipulation via registration of chiropractors and osteopaths; (b) the Federal Government finds tertiary education at that standard; and (c) the State and Territory Governments license graduates of those courses: does the undergraduate education in medicine provide equivalent education and clinical experience in the following non-medical procedures to equip general practitioners to practice: (a) iridology; (b) ozone therapy; (c) remedial massage; (d) herbal medicine; (e) naturopathy; (f) homoeopathy; (g) chiropractic/osteopathy; and (h) acupuncture; if not, what post graduate education and clinical experience is needed to equate general practitioners with the unique competency in these areas.

(3) Do medical registration boards require a distinct equivalent qualification prior to medical practitioners being permitted to hold themselves out to practice and charge for: (a) iridology; (b) ozone therapy; (c) remedial massage; (d) herbal medicine; (e) naturopathy; (f) homoeopathy; (g) chiropractic/osteopathy; and (h) acupuncture; if not, where did the medical profession acquire its educational and research background in these areas.

(4) What government body sets the prerequisite educational and clinical experience requirements for Medicare reimbursements, if any) in: (a) iridology; (b) ozone therapy; (c) remedial massage; (d) herbal medicine; (e) naturopathy; (f) homoeopathy; (g) chiropractic/osteopathy; and (h) acupuncture.
(5) How does Medicare differentiate between general practitioners who have no training in each of these modalities and those who have attained equivalent standards.
(6) What is the minimum post-graduate education and clinical experience in spinal manipulation required by Medicare prior to reimbursing that service by a general practitioner.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the follow ing answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Medicare benefits are payable for professional services listed in the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) on the proviso that the service is clinically relevant and rendered by a medical practitioner. A clinically relevant service is one which is generally accepted in the medical profession as being necessary for the appropriate treatment of the patient to whom it is rendered.

Ozone therapy, remedial massage, herbal medicine, naturopathy, homoeopathy, chiropractic/osteopathy, acupuncture and iridology are not specifically listed as services in the MBS. Medicare benefits would be payable for the consultation by a medical practitioner at which these services were performed, if all the requirements of the relevant consultation item descriptor were met and the services were considered to be clinically relevant.
(2) The regulation of health care, including the regulation of medical practice and registration of medical practitioners, is a State matter.

It is understood that States do not currently require providers of iridology, ozone therapy, remedial massage, herbal medicine, naturopathy, homoeopathy or acupuncture to be registered. In the absence of any agreed standard within these areas of practice, it is impossible to speculate what level of education or experience a medical practitioner would require to obtain an equivalent level of competency in these areas.

In relation to chiropractic/osteopathy it is understood that State Chiropractors Boards are responsible for registering all practitioners, including medical practitioners who wish to call themselves chiropractors. The issue of what level of training a medical practitioner must meet in order to call themselves a chiropractor is therefore a matter for the State Chiropractors Boards.

(3) The requirements of registration with State medical boards is a State matter. However, it is understood that medical boards (State Chiropractors Boards are not medical boards) do not require a medical practitioner to provide them with details of qualifications in relation to iridology, ozone therapy, remedial massage, herbal medicine, naturopathy, homoeopathy, chiropractic/osteopathy or acupuncture before the medical practitioner can provide such services.

It is not possible to state how the medical profession as a whole acquired its educational and research background into the areas of iridology, ozone therapy, remedial massage, herbal medicine, naturopathy, homoeopathy, chiropractic/osteopathy or acupuncture.

In the absence of any regulation or recognised training options, it is generally expected that it is the professional responsibility of individual medical practitioners to ensure that they are appropriately qualified to provide any particular service. This general principle would apply equally to services relating to iridology, ozone therapy, remedial massage, herbal medicine, naturopathy, homoeopathy, chiropractic/osteopathy and acupuncture.

It is also understood that training specifically targeted at medical practitioners in some areas, such as acupuncture, is available through the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP). In the case of acupuncture there is also a body, the Australian Medical Acupuncture Society (AMAS), which represents medical acupuncturists and is working with the RACGP to develop appropriate training and standards for medical acupuncturists.

(4) There is no government body that sets prerequisite educational and clinical experience requirements for Medicare reimbursements in relation to iridology, ozone therapy, remedial massage, herbal medicine, naturopathy, homoeopathy, chiropractic/osteopathy or acupuncture.

(5) The Commonwealth does not discriminate between general practitioners that have n training in iridology, ozone therapy, remedial massage, herbal medicine, naturopathy, homoeopathy or acupuncture, and those who have not for the purposes of paying Medicare benefits.

As mentioned above, Medicare benefits are only payable for services which are generally accepted by the medical profession as being necessary for the appropriate treatment of the patient. Where the Health Insurance Commission suspects that a doctor is involved in inappropriate medical practice, provisions exist through the Professional Services Review Scheme for the practitioner's activities to be assessed by their peers.

(6) There is no minimum post graduate education of clinical experience in spina] manipulation required prior to Medicare benefits being paid to a patient for spinal manipulation performed by a medical practitioner. Medicare benefits are not payable for spinal manipulation per se, but for a clinically relevant consultation at which spinal manipulation may be performed.
